MOVEMENT 3: UNFORCED RHYTHMS (The Transformation)

Chapter 11: Redemption's Story

[audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/Redemption-Story.mp3"] You've been reading your story as if it's self-contained. Your swamp. Your rescue. Your journey. And while those details are uniquely yours, the pattern isn't. The arc you're walking—from brokenness to redemption, from death to life, from exile to homecoming—isn't new. It's ancient. Older than your grandparents. Older than civilization. Older than the stars. This is the pattern woven through all of history: creation, fall, redemption, restoration. Eden lost and paradise regained. Exile and return. Death and resurrection. Here's what changes everything: your story isn't separate from that larger story. It's part of it. A thread in the tapestry. A verse in the song. A particular expression of THE redemption story that's been unfolding since before time began. When you grasp this—when you really see your story within God's story—everything shifts. The pain has purpose. The waiting has meaning. The struggle isn't random. Because you're not just surviving your circumstances. You're participating in the grand narrative of redemption that gives meaning to all of creation. This chapter is about seeing the bigger picture. Understanding how your personal story fits into God's cosmic story. Discovering that the God who promised redemption in Eden, who delivered Israel from Egypt, who raised Jesus from the dead, is the same God writing your story right now. You're not the author. But you're not a footnote either. You're a beloved character in the greatest story ever told—the story of how God redeems everything.

Key Themes

1. The Gospel as THE Story Christianity isn't one religious option among many. It's THE story—the metanarrative that makes sense of all other stories. The framework within which human history unfolds. The lens through which we understand who we are, why we're here, what went wrong, and how it's being made right. N.T. Wright writes in Simply Christian:
"The story of Jesus isn't one religious tale among many. It's the story the whole world has been waiting for. It's the story of how the Creator God became human to rescue His creation, to defeat evil, to launch His new creation project. When you grasp this story, you see everything differently." — N.T. Wright, Simply Christian
The redemption story has a clear arc: Creation - God makes everything good. Humanity is created in His image, designed for relationship with Him, given purpose and dignity and calling. Fall - Sin enters through human rebellion. The image is marred. Relationship is broken. Creation is cursed. Death enters the world. Humanity is exiled from Eden. Redemption - God doesn't abandon His creation. He promises a Savior. He calls a people. He gives the Law to reveal sin and point to grace. He sends prophets to declare His faithfulness. And then—in the fullness of time—He sends His Son. Jesus, the eternal Word, becomes flesh. Lives the perfect life we couldn't live. Dies the death we deserved. Rises victorious over sin and death. Accomplishes redemption. Restoration - The story isn't finished. Jesus ascended but promised to return. He's building His Church. He's reconciling all things to Himself. And one day—the day we're waiting for—He will return to judge the living and the dead, to make all things new, to restore creation to what it was always meant to be. No more curse. No more tears. No more death. The New Jerusalem descending. God dwelling with His people forever. This is THE story. Every other story—every myth, every legend, every fairy tale, every personal narrative—echoes this one. Because this is the true story of the world. And you're in it. 2. Your Story Within God's Story Your personal narrative isn't separate from God's narrative. It's woven into it. Your redemption story is a particular expression of THE redemption story. When you were in the swamp, you weren't just struggling with personal sin. You were experiencing the effects of the fall—the brokenness that entered creation when humanity rebelled against God. When you cried out for help, you weren't just praying for relief. You were participating in the pattern of human cry and divine response that runs throughout Scripture. From Adam and Eve hiding in the garden to the Israelites groaning in Egypt to David fleeing from Saul to Jonah in the fish to the tax collector beating his breast—God hears the cry of His people and responds with redemption. When you encountered grace at the water's edge, you weren't just having a personal religious experience. You were meeting the same God who appeared to Moses in the burning bush, who led Israel through the Red Sea, who sent His Son to seek and save the lost. When you died to self and rose in new life, you weren't just turning over a new leaf. You were participating in the death and resurrection of Jesus. United with Him in His death. Raised with Him in His resurrection. A new creation. The old has gone, the new has come. Lesslie Newbigin writes in The Gospel in a Pluralist Society:
"To be converted is not to turn from one religion to another. It's to be brought into the true story of the world. To discover that your life has meaning because it's part of God's great redemption project." — Lesslie Newbigin, The Gospel in a Pluralist Society
Your story matters because it's part of God's story. The specifics are yours—your swamp is different from mine, your water's edge encounter is unique, your rhythms and roots look different than anyone else's. But the pattern is universal. The arc is the same. The Author is writing both your story and the cosmic story, and they fit together perfectly. 3. Nothing Wasted One of the most powerful promises in the redemption story is this: nothing is wasted. Every pain, every struggle, every broken place, every hard season—God is weaving it all into the tapestry of redemption. Romans 8:28 captures this promise:
"And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose."
Notice: Paul doesn't say all things are good. They're not. Sin is evil. Suffering is real. Brokenness hurts. But he does say God works in all things for good. He's taking even the broken pieces—especially the broken pieces—and weaving them into a story of redemption. Joseph's story is the perfect illustration. Betrayed by his brothers. Sold into slavery. Falsely accused. Imprisoned. Forgotten. But God was at work the whole time. And when Joseph finally sees the bigger story—when he's reunited with his brothers—he can say:
"You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives." — Genesis 50:20
You intended harm. God intended good. Not that God caused the harm. But that He redeemed it. He took what was meant for destruction and turned it into salvation. This is the promise for you: the years you spent in the swamp aren't wasted. God is redeeming them. The pain you experienced isn't meaningless. God is using it. The struggles that nearly broke you are being transformed into testimonies that will strengthen others. Fleming Rutledge writes in The Crucifixion:
"The cross is God's answer to the problem of evil. Not that He explains it. But that He enters into it, bears it, transforms it. At the cross, the worst thing that ever happened—the murder of the Son of God—becomes the best thing that ever happened—the redemption of the world. If God can redeem that, He can redeem anything." — Fleming Rutledge, The Crucifixion
Nothing is wasted. Not in God's economy. He's the master of turning crucifixions into resurrections, tombs into triumphs, endings into new beginnings. 4. The Redemption Arc From Creation Through Consummation The redemption story isn't just a moment—Jesus dying on the cross. It's an arc. A trajectory. A movement from creation through fall through redemption toward restoration. And you're living in the middle of that arc. Creation - You were made in God's image. Before you ever sinned, before you ever fell, you had dignity and worth and purpose because you were created by God, for God, to reflect God. Fall - Sin marred that image. Your swamp—whatever form it took—was a manifestation of the fall. The brokenness in you, around you, because of you. The curse. The exile from Eden. Redemption - Jesus came to rescue you. Not just your soul, but all of you. He didn't die to take you out of this world but to redeem you in it. To make you a new creation. To begin the work of restoration. Restoration - This is where you are now. Living between "already" and "not yet." Already redeemed. Not yet fully restored. The redemption is secured but the restoration is ongoing. You're being transformed from glory to glory. Growing in grace. Becoming more like Jesus. The roots are deepening. The fruit is coming. But it's not finished yet. Consummation - One day, Jesus will return. And everything broken will be made whole. Every tear will be wiped away. Every wrong will be made right. No more swamps. No more struggle. Full restoration. Complete redemption. You'll stand before Him—fully redeemed, completely restored—and you'll spend eternity in unbroken fellowship with the God who created you, pursued you, redeemed you, and restored you. Michael Gorman writes in Becoming the Gospel:
"The gospel isn't just about how to go to heaven when you die. It's about how heaven comes to earth through Jesus and His people. It's about God's project to restore all of creation—starting with you." — Michael Gorman, Becoming the Gospel
You're part of that project. Not as a passive recipient. As an active participant. God is restoring you so you can participate in His work of restoring the world. 5. Joseph, Peter, Paul: Examples of Redemption The Bible is full of stories that illustrate the redemption arc. Let's look at three: Joseph: From Pit to Palace Joseph's story is betrayal to blessing. His brothers throw him in a pit, sell him into slavery. He's falsely accused, imprisoned, forgotten. But God is at work. Joseph rises to become second-in-command in Egypt. When famine comes, he's positioned to save his entire family—the same brothers who betrayed him. And when they're finally reconciled, Joseph can see the redemption arc:
"You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good."
The pit wasn't wasted. The prison wasn't meaningless. God was positioning Joseph for purpose. Redeeming the broken pieces into a story of salvation. Peter: From Denial to Boldness Peter's story is failure to faithfulness. He swears he'll never deny Jesus. Then denies Him three times. The rooster crows. Peter weeps bitterly. But Jesus doesn't write Peter off. After the resurrection, Jesus seeks Peter out. Three denials, three affirmations: "Do you love me? Feed my sheep." Restoration. Redemption. Recommissioning. And the Peter who denied Jesus becomes the Peter who preaches at Pentecost. Bold. Courageous. Faithful unto death. His failure wasn't the end of his story. It was the beginning of his redemption arc. Paul: From Persecutor to Apostle Paul's story is violence to mission. He's breathing threats against Christians. Dragging them to prison. Approving Stephen's murder. But Jesus meets him on the Damascus road. Blinds him. Calls him. Transforms him. And the persecutor becomes the apostle. The one who tried to destroy the church becomes the one who builds it across the Roman Empire. The murderer becomes the missionary. Paul never forgets his past. But he sees it redeemed:
"I was once a blasphemer and a persecutor and a violent man... But I was shown mercy... so that in me, the worst of sinners, Christ Jesus might display his immense patience as an example for those who would believe." — 1 Timothy 1:13-16
His worst moments become testimonies to God's greatest grace. Nothing wasted. Scot McKnight writes in The King Jesus Gospel:
"The gospel isn't just a message to be believed. It's a story to be entered. When you hear these redemption stories—Joseph, Peter, Paul—you're not just reading about them. You're seeing the pattern of your own story. Betrayal redeemed. Failure restored. Violence transformed. This is what God does." — Scot McKnight, The King Jesus Gospel
6. Living as Part of the Larger Story When you grasp that your story is part of God's story, it changes how you live. You live with purpose. Your life isn't random. You're not wandering aimlessly. You're part of God's redemption project. Every choice matters. Every day has meaning. You're being formed for eternity. You live with hope. No matter how hard today is, you know the ending. The story doesn't end with suffering. It ends with restoration. Jesus returns. All things are made new. The tears are wiped away. The curse is removed. You live in light of that promised future. You live with perseverance. The struggles you face aren't meaningless. They're part of the redemption arc. God is using them to shape you, refine you, prepare you for the role you'll play in His kingdom. So you don't give up. You keep going. Because you know the Author is still writing. You live with mission. You're not just receiving redemption. You're participating in it. God redeems you so you can be part of His redemptive work in the world. You bring light into dark places. Hope into despair. Grace into brokenness. You're an ambassador of the redemption story. You live with gratitude. When you see the whole arc—creation, fall, redemption, restoration, consummation—you're overwhelmed by grace. You didn't earn this. You didn't deserve it. But God, in His great love, wrote you into His story. Pursued you in the swamp. Met you at the water's edge. Raised you to new life. And He's not done yet. This is redemption's story. And it's your story too.

Biblical Parallels

The Redemption Promise in Eden (Genesis 3:15) The moment sin enters the world, God speaks a promise of redemption:
"And I will put enmity between you and the woman, and between your offspring and hers; he will crush your head, and you will strike his heel." — Genesis 3:15
This is the first gospel proclamation—the protoevangelium. Even as God pronounces the curse, He promises redemption. A seed of the woman will come who will crush the serpent's head. The entire Old Testament is the unfolding of this promise. Through Abraham, through Isaac, through Jacob, through David—the line is preserved. The promise is passed down. Until finally, in the fullness of time, the Seed comes: Jesus, born of a woman, who crushes the serpent's head at the cross. Redemption wasn't an afterthought. It was promised from the beginning. God's Plan to Unite All Things (Ephesians 1:9-10) Paul reveals the scope of God's redemption plan:
"He made known to us the mystery of his will according to his good pleasure, which he purposed in Christ, to be put into effect when the times reach their fulfillment—to bring unity to all things in heaven and on earth under Christ." — Ephesians 1:9-10
God's plan isn't just to save individual souls. It's to unite ALL things under Christ. Heaven and earth. Spiritual and physical. Every tribe, tongue, and nation. All of creation groaning for redemption will be restored. This is the cosmic scope of the redemption story. Nothing left out. Nothing excluded. All things brought under Christ's lordship. All things made new. New Creation (2 Corinthians 5:17) Paul describes what happens when you enter the redemption story:
"Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: The old has gone, the new is here!" — 2 Corinthians 5:17
You're not just reformed. You're re-created. Not just improved. Made new. This is the redemption arc applied to individual lives: what was dead is brought to life. What was broken is made whole. What was enslaved is set free. New creation doesn't mean perfection yet. But it means the redemption process has begun. You're being transformed. The old patterns are losing their power. The new life is growing. And one day, the new creation will be complete. Behold, I Am Making All Things New (Revelation 21:5) The redemption story reaches its climax in Revelation:
"He who was seated on the throne said, 'I am making everything new!' Then he said, 'Write this down, for these words are trustworthy and true.'" — Revelation 21:5
Notice the tense: "I AM making." Not "I will make." Not "I made." Present progressive. God is actively, right now, in the process of making all things new. You're living in the "making new" phase. The restoration has begun but isn't finished. The kingdom has been inaugurated but not yet consummated. Jesus has won the victory but hasn't yet returned to fully implement it. But He will. And when He does, the redemption story will be complete. New heaven. New earth. No more tears. No more death. All things made new. This is the promise that gives hope to every wayfarer still walking through the wilderness: the story ends with restoration. Complete. Total. Eternal. Redemption.

Theological Anchor

"And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose. For those God foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brothers and sisters. And those he predestined, he also called; those he called, he also justified; those he justified, he also glorified." — Romans 8:28-30
This is the redemption arc applied to individual lives. Let's unpack it: "In all things God works for the good" Not some things. All things. Not just the good experiences. All experiences. God is at work in the swamp and at the water's edge, in the dying and in the rising, in the valleys and on the mountains. This doesn't mean all things are good. They're not. Sin is evil. Suffering is real. Brokenness hurts. But it does mean God is working in all things. Taking even the broken pieces and weaving them into a story of redemption. Nothing is outside His reach. Nothing is beyond His ability to redeem. "For the good of those who love him" The promise is conditional. Not universally applied. It's for those who love God—who are in relationship with Him, who trust Him, who have responded to His call. If you're outside the redemption story, this promise doesn't apply. But if you've entered it—if you've responded to God's call, trusted in Jesus, been brought into the family—then this promise is yours. God is working all things for your good. Not for your comfort. Not for your ease. But for your ultimate good—conformity to Christ, participation in His kingdom, eternal glory with Him. "Who have been called according to his purpose" You didn't stumble into the redemption story by accident. You were called. God pursued you. Drew you. Opened your eyes to see your need and His provision. This calling has a purpose: not just your salvation but your participation in God's redemptive work. You're called to be conformed to Christ's image, to be salt and light in the world, to participate in the restoration of all things. "Predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son" Here's the goal: conformity to Jesus. Not perfection in this life. But progressive transformation until, one day, you're fully like Him. This is what the redemption story accomplishes in you. You were created in God's image. Sin marred that image. Jesus came to restore it. And through the Spirit's work—in the rhythms of grace, through deep roots, in community and Scripture and prayer—you're being transformed into His likeness. "Called... justified... glorified" Paul traces the redemption arc in three movements: Called - God pursued you. Spoke to you. Drew you to Himself. Your "yes" wasn't the beginning—God's call was. Justified - You were declared righteous. Not because you earned it. But because Jesus' righteousness was credited to you. You stand before God forgiven, accepted, beloved—not based on your performance but on Christ's finished work. Glorified - Past tense. Even though it's future. Why? Because in God's eternal perspective, it's already done. The story is written. The ending is secure. You will be glorified—fully redeemed, completely restored, eternally with Christ. This is the theological anchor: your redemption is part of God's eternal purpose. He foreknew you. Predestined you. Called you. Justified you. And He will glorify you. The story isn't in doubt. The ending is secure. You're part of THE redemption story, and nothing can separate you from that.

The Wayfarer Moment

Seeing my story in THE story. For years, I thought my story was just mine. My struggles. My failures. My small attempts to get it right. I'd read the Bible as ancient history—good for principles, maybe, but not personally connected to my everyday life. But then I started to see it. The pattern of my life—swamp, water's edge, dying, rising, rhythms, roots—wasn't unique to me. It was the redemption arc. The same arc that runs through Scripture from Genesis to Revelation. From Eden to the New Jerusalem. I wasn't just struggling with personal sin. I was experiencing the fall. I wasn't just crying out for help. I was participating in the pattern of cry and divine response that echoes through the Psalms. I wasn't just encountering grace. I was meeting the same God who met Moses, David, Peter, Paul. I wasn't just dying to self. I was being united with Christ in His death and resurrection. My story was part of THE story. And when I saw that—really saw it—everything changed. The pain I'd experienced wasn't meaningless. It was part of the redemption arc. God was using it to conform me to Christ's image, to prepare me for the role I'd play in His kingdom. The waiting seasons weren't wasted. They were necessary parts of the story. Times of preparation. Seasons of root-deepening. Wilderness experiences that would later become testimonies. The failures I'd carried with shame weren't the end of my story. They were chapters in a larger redemption narrative. Like Peter's denial. Like Paul's persecution. Like Joseph's pit. God was redeeming them, transforming them into testimonies of grace. The wayfarer moment came when I stopped seeing my life as disconnected events and started seeing it as a coherent narrative—my story woven into God's story. I'm not the author. I'm a character. But I'm a beloved character in a story written by a good Author who knows how to turn crucifixions into resurrections. I don't know how my particular story will unfold. I don't know what chapters are ahead. But I know the Author. I know the arc. I know the ending. Creation. Fall. Redemption. Restoration. Consummation. And I know that in all things—ALL things—God is working for good. Nothing is wasted. Every pain has purpose. Every struggle is part of the redemption arc. This is THE story. And by grace, it's my story too.

Original Writing from the Blog

Note: The song "Redemption Story" serves as both the original writing and the song for this chapter, telling the complete gospel narrative from creation through consummation.

Song Integration

The Season of Fragmentation: For years, my life felt like disconnected pieces. Random events. Unrelated struggles. Pain here, joy there, failure in one season, growth in another—but no coherent thread tying it all together. I looked at my story and saw chaos. Mistakes I couldn't undo. Seasons that felt wasted. Suffering that seemed meaningless. I was drowning in the particulars of my own narrative, unable to see any pattern or purpose. Questions haunted me: Why did that relationship fail? Why did I waste those years in the swamp? Why did God allow that betrayal? What was the point of all that pain? I was so focused on my own story—my struggles, my failures, my journey—that I'd lost sight of THE story. The grand narrative of redemption that's been unfolding since before the foundation of the world. The Shift: The turning point came during a season of deep study. Several authors helped me see the Bible not as a collection of disconnected morality tales, but as one coherent story with a single redemption arc. Creation → Fall → Israel → Incarnation → Cross & Resurrection → Church → Consummation. And slowly—painfully slowly—I began to see: my story wasn't random. It was part of THE story. The pain I'd experienced? Part of the redemption arc—God conforming me to Christ's image through suffering. The waiting seasons? Not wasted, but necessary. Wilderness experiences preparing me for what was ahead. The failures? Like Peter's denial. Like Paul's persecution. Like Joseph's pit. God was redeeming them, weaving them into a larger narrative of grace. Romans 8:28 clicked in a new way: "All things work together for good for those who love God and are called according to His purpose." Not all things are good. But all things—even the painful, broken, seemingly wasted things—are being worked together into a redemptive purpose. What This Song Does: This song is my attempt to tell THE story. Not just the cross (though the cross is central). The whole story. From creation through consummation. The full redemption arc. Because the gospel isn't just a moment—Jesus dying for my sins. It's a story. THE story. The story that makes sense of all other stories. I wanted to trace redemption history chronologically:
  • Creation (before the stars): God speaks, and everything comes to be. We're made in His image. Designed for relationship.
  • The Fall (Eden's garden): The serpent's lie. Sin enters. Yet even then, a Savior is promised.
  • The Prophecies (kings and prophets): David's line. Isaiah's suffering servant. God's faithfulness across centuries.
  • The Incarnation (Mary's baby boy): The Word becomes flesh. Divinity wrapped in humanity.
  • The Crucifixion (betrayal, denial, cross): Leaders scheme. Friends betray. Yet grace triumphs. Death is undone.
  • Personal Application (to die with Christ): My story entwined with His. What was broken is being redeemed.
  • Eternal Hope (forever His own): One day we'll stand before His throne. Forever redeemed.
And when you see your story within that larger story, everything changes. Why This Song is Both Writing and Response: For this chapter, there is no separate devotional. The song itself is the writing. The proclamation. The declaration. Because sometimes, the most powerful response to a fragmented life is to tell THE story—to trace the redemption arc from beginning to end and recognize: I'm in this story. My pain, my waiting, my failures—they're being woven into this grand narrative of redemption. The song doesn't answer all my questions. It doesn't explain why specific things happened. But it does something more important: it locates my story within God's story. And that reframing—from "why did this happen to me?" to "how does this fit into God's redemption arc?"—is transformative. Where my life felt chaotic, THE story reveals purpose. Where my pain felt meaningless, THE story reveals redemption. Where my failures felt final, THE story reveals resurrection. I don't know how all the pieces of my story fit together yet. I don't see the full picture. But I know the Author. I know the arc. I know the ending. Creation. Fall. Redemption. Restoration. Consummation. And by grace—scandalous, undeserved, transforming grace—my story is part of THE story. That's why I sing it. To remember. To proclaim. To anchor myself in the truth that the God who began a good work in creation will complete it in consummation—and my life, with all its brokenness, is part of that beautiful, redemptive arc. The song moves chronologically through redemption history: Creation - Before the stars, before the sun, the Word spoke and everything came to be. We were made in His image. Designed for relationship with Him. The Fall - Eden's garden. The serpent's lie. The fruit taken. Sin entering. Yet even then, God's love remained. A Savior promised. The Prophecies - Kings and prophets declaring God's truth. David's line. Isaiah's suffering servant. Elijah's fire. Daniel's stand. God's faithfulness across the land. The Incarnation - Mary chosen. Holding her baby boy. Did she know the cross He'd face? Through grief, she trusted. Through loss, she prayed. The Betrayal and Crucifixion - Leaders scheming. Betrayed by a kiss. Denied by a friend. Yet grace would triumph. Death undone. Victory through God's risen Son. Personal Application - To die with Christ. To rise anew. My story now entwined with His. A song of hope. A life that lives. Eternal Hope - His story echoes through all of time. One day we'll stand before His throne. Forever redeemed. Forever His own. This is the redemption story. From beginning to end. From creation to consummation. From "Let there be light" to "I am making all things new." And it's not just ancient history. It's the story you're living in.

Song: "Redemption Story"

Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Verse 1: Before the stars adorned the night, Before the sun gave earth its light, The Word was spoken, creation came, Through Jesus, the Maker, who knew our name. He formed the earth, the skies, the seas, Breathed life into humanity. From dust we rose, His Spirit's flame, To bear His image, to praise His name. Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Verse 2: In Eden's garden, peace was found, Until the serpent's lie unbound. The fruit was taken, the fall began, Sin entered the hearts of every man. Yet even then, God's love remained, A Savior promised to break the chain. From Adam's sin to grace restored, A plan of redemption from the Lord. Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Verse 3: Through kings and prophets, His voice was heard, Declaring His truth, His holy word. David, the shepherd, a king would rise, Through his line, the Savior arrive. Isaiah spoke of a suffering King, Who'd bear our sins and salvation bring. Elijah's fire, Daniel's stand, God's faithfulness across the land. Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Bridge: Oh, the cross, where mercy flows, The empty grave, the story shows. Sin defeated, love prevailed, Through Christ alone, redemption hailed. Oh, the cross, where hope is found, His grace abounds, His love profound. He bore the weight, the debt was paid, In Him, the victory's displayed. Verse 4: Mary, chosen, her heart so pure, Through her, God's love would long endure. She held the Savior, her baby boy, The King of kings, her heart's great joy. Did she know the cross He'd face, The pain, the nails, the world's disgrace? Through grief, she trusted, through loss, she prayed, Believing in the plan God made. Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Verse 5: The leaders schemed, their hearts grew cold, Blinded by power, they sought control. They called Him a blasphemer, sentenced His death, Yet love endured with His final breath. Betrayed by a kiss for silver's gleam, Denied by a friend in a broken dream. Yet grace would triumph, death undone, Victory through God's risen Son. Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Verse 6: To die with Christ, to rise anew, To walk His path, His love pursue. The cross became the bridge to grace, A gift of life in His embrace. Through history's thread, His story flows, A love eternal, a truth that grows. My story now entwined with His, A song of hope, a life that lives. Final Chorus: From the beginning, His love was displayed, Through every fall, His promise stayed. A Savior's grace, a story divine, Redemption secured for hearts like mine. Outro: His story echoes through all of time, A Savior's love, so pure, so kind. One day we'll stand before His throne, Forever redeemed, forever His own.

Reflections for the Road

These aren't academic exercises. They're invitations to see your story within THE story. Questions for the Journey:
  1. Where do you see your story fitting into the redemption arc? Creation - Do you recognize that you were made in God's image? That before the swamp, before the brokenness, you had dignity and worth and purpose simply because God created you? Fall - Can you name your swamp? Your particular experience of brokenness? The ways sin marred the image? Redemption - Where have you encountered God's grace? What was your water's edge moment? How has Jesus rescued you? Restoration - Where are you now in the "making new" process? What old patterns are dying? What new life is growing? Consummation - Do you live with hope for the final restoration? The day when all things are made new?
  2. What parts of your story feel wasted? Can you trust God to redeem them? Years in the swamp. Relationships broken. Opportunities lost. Time you can't get back. Can you trust that God is a master at redeeming wasted years? That He's taking even the broken pieces and weaving them into a testimony of grace? Read Genesis 50:20 slowly. "You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good." Can you believe that for your story?
  3. Whose redemption story encourages you? Joseph - from pit to palace. Peter - from denial to boldness. Paul - from persecutor to apostle. Or someone you know personally. Someone whose story demonstrates that God redeems broken pieces. Let their story give you hope for yours. The same God who wrote their redemption arc is writing yours.
  4. How does seeing your story within God's story change how you live today? Does it give you purpose? Hope? Perseverance? Mission? Gratitude? What would change if you really believed your life has meaning because it's part of God's grand redemption project?
  5. Read Ephesians 1:9-10 and Revelation 21:5. How do these verses shape your hope? God's plan is to unite ALL things under Christ. To make ALL things new. You're part of that plan. Your redemption is part of God's project to restore all of creation. How does that cosmic scope give meaning to your personal story?

Practice: Telling Your Redemption Story

One of the most powerful spiritual practices is learning to tell your redemption story—not just for others, but for yourself. To see the arc. To recognize God's faithfulness. To remember where you've been and where you're going. Here's a simple framework: 1. Creation - Who you were made to be Before the swamp. Before the brokenness. Who did God create you to be? This isn't about romanticizing the past. It's about recognizing the image of God in you—the dignity and worth you have simply because you were created by God, for God. What gifts did He give you? What longings? What was the original design before sin marred it? 2. Fall - Your swamp Name it. Be specific. What was your particular experience of brokenness? Addiction? Shame? Abuse? Betrayal? Pride? Performance-driven religion? Despair? Don't sugarcoat it. Don't minimize it. The fall was real. The swamp was deep. Acknowledge it. 3. Redemption - Your water's edge encounter When did you meet grace? What was your turning point? Maybe it was dramatic—a moment of crisis and divine intervention. Maybe it was gradual—a slow awakening to God's presence. Either way, tell the story. How did God pursue you? When did you respond? What changed? 4. Restoration - The journey since then This is where you are now. Between "already redeemed" and "not yet fully restored." What has God been doing in you since the water's edge? What rhythms have you learned? What roots have you grown? What fruit has come? Be honest about the ongoing struggle. Restoration is a process, not a moment. There are victories and setbacks. Growth and pruning. Progress and patience. 5. Consummation - The hope ahead How does the promise of final restoration shape how you live now? One day, all things will be made new. Fully. Completely. Eternally. You'll stand before Jesus—fully redeemed, completely restored—and you'll spend forever in His presence. How does that hope sustain you in hard seasons? How does it give meaning to the struggles you face now? 6. Share your story Your redemption story isn't just for you. It's a testimony of God's faithfulness that can encourage others. Find someone to share it with. A friend. A small group. Someone who's still in the swamp and needs to hear that redemption is possible. Don't perform it. Just tell it. Honestly. Humbly. With gratitude for the God who pursued you, redeemed you, and is still at work making you new. Your story matters. Not because you're special. But because the Author is faithful. And when people hear your story, they hear echoes of THE story—the redemption narrative that gives hope to every wayfarer.

Closing Image

You're standing at the edge of a vast tapestry. So large you can't see the whole thing. So intricate you can't count the threads. But you can see your section. The part you've been working on. The threads you've been weaving. From up close, it looks messy. Dark threads mixed with light. Broken places where the pattern seems chaotic. Sections you'd rather cut out and start over. But then you step back. And you begin to see it. Your dark threads aren't mistakes. They're part of the design. The broken places aren't flaws. They're contrast that makes the bright threads shine brighter. You step back further. And you see that your section connects to other sections. Your story is woven into other stories. The threads intertwine. The patterns complement each other. This isn't just your tapestry. It's part of something much larger. You step back even further—as far as you can see. And though you still can't see the whole tapestry, you begin to glimpse the scope. It stretches back before you can see—to creation, to Eden, to the beginning of all things. And it stretches forward beyond your vision—to restoration, to the New Jerusalem, to eternity. This is THE tapestry. The redemption story. God's grand narrative into which every smaller story is woven. And your threads—every joy and sorrow, every triumph and failure, every moment of grace and every season of struggle—are woven into the larger design. Nothing is wasted. Nothing is random. Everything is part of the pattern. You can't see the whole picture yet. But you know the Weaver. And you trust that He knows what He's doing. One day—when the tapestry is complete, when the final thread is woven, when Jesus returns and all things are made new—you'll see it. The whole story. From creation to consummation. Every thread in its place. Every pattern intentional. Every dark section necessary to make the bright sections shine. And you'll see your story woven perfectly into His story. Not as an accident. Not as an afterthought. But as a beloved thread in the grand redemption narrative. And you'll worship the Weaver who took your broken threads and wove them into something beautiful. This is redemption's story. From the beginning, His love was displayed. Through every fall, His promise stayed. And the story isn't finished. He's still weaving. Still making all things new. Still writing the redemption narrative that will one day culminate in complete restoration. You're part of that story. Not a footnote. Not a side character. A beloved participant in God's grand project to redeem and restore all of creation. Your story matters because it's part of THE story. And the Author is faithful. From beginning to end. From creation to consummation. From "Let there be light" to "Behold, I am making all things new." This is the redemption story. And by grace—amazing, undeserved, transforming grace—it's your story too. Forever redeemed. Forever His own.

📢 "Dying Changes Everything: A Wayfarer's Journey" is being replaced by Out of the Swamp: How I found TRUTH

MOVEMENT 3: UNFORCED RHYTHMS (The Transformation)

Chapter 12: Nothing is Wasted

[audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/Nothing-is-Wasted-Remastered.mp3"] There's a peculiar grief that comes from looking back at your life and seeing waste. Not just mistakes—those are forgivable. Not just failures—those can be redeemed. But waste. Time lost that you can never recover. Years spent in patterns that brought nothing but destruction. Relationships damaged beyond repair. Potential squandered. Opportunities missed. You look at your timeline and see seasons that feel like black holes—years where nothing good grew, nothing valuable was learned, nothing redemptive emerged. Just waste. And the question haunts you: Can God really redeem this? Or are some things just... lost? This is where grace reveals one of its most scandalous promises: in God's economy, nothing is wasted. Not "almost nothing." Not "most things." Nothing. Every tear. Every failure. Every lost year. Every broken relationship. Every season you wish you could erase from your story—God can redeem it all. This doesn't mean the pain wasn't real or the consequences don't matter. It means God specializes in turning crucifixions into resurrections. He takes what looks like absolute waste and transforms it into raw material for redemption. This chapter is about learning to see your timeline through the lens of grace. Not with denial that pretends the waste wasn't real. But with faith that believes God can redeem even what seems irredeemable. That the years you thought were lost have been woven into a larger story of transformation. That nothing—absolutely nothing—is wasted in His hands.

Key Themes

1. Timeline Reflection: The Sacred Work of Looking Back Part of believing nothing is wasted is doing the hard work of timeline reflection. Not to dwell in the past, but to understand how the past has shaped the present. This isn't nostalgia. It's not rumination. It's the intentional practice of asking:
  • What moments brought joy?
  • What moments brought pain?
  • What patterns emerged?
  • Where was grace at work even when I couldn't see it?
Timothy Keller writes in Walking with God Through Pain and Suffering:
"If we look back on our lives with eyes of faith, we will see that even in our darkest times God's providence was lovingly at work. We may not have seen it at the time, but looking back we can trace his hand." — Timothy Keller, Walking with God Through Pain and Suffering
Timeline reflection requires courage. It means looking honestly at seasons you'd rather forget. But it also reveals something profound: grace was present even when you couldn't feel it. God was working even when you couldn't see it. The wayfarer who refuses to look back misses the evidence of grace. But the one who looks back with eyes of faith sees a thread—sometimes golden, sometimes crimson—woven through every season. The thread of redemption. The thread that says: nothing is wasted. 2. Counting the Cost: Present and Future Timeline reflection looks backward. But the work of "nothing is wasted" also requires looking forward—counting the cost of present choices. This isn't just about past choices and their consequences. It's about present ones. What kind of life do I want to live now? What brings me life? What drains me? Am I pursuing what's actually fulfilling, or just what's familiar? Jerry Sittser writes in A Grace Disguised:
"The experience of loss does not have to be the defining moment of our story. The defining moment can be our response to the loss. We will know who we are by the choices we make." — Jerry Sittser, A Grace Disguised
When nothing is wasted, even the hard questions become tools for growth. The questions themselves are grace—invitations to live more intentionally, more authentically, more aligned with who God is calling you to become. Counting the cost means asking: If my future self could speak to me today, what would they want me to know? What choices would they be grateful I made? What patterns would they wish I'd broken sooner? This isn't anxiety about the future. It's wisdom. It's stewarding today in light of tomorrow. It's believing that even this moment—this choice, this breath, this step—matters eternally. 3. Redeeming Relational Complexity Family relationships can be minefields. You say something with one intention, it's received with another meaning. You offer help, it's taken as criticism. You try to be sensitive, you're told you're being "too sensitive." These moments feel wasted—painful miscommunications that just add to the pile of relational scar tissue. But when viewed through the lens of redemption, even these become opportunities. Opportunities to practice patience. To extend grace. To choose different responses. Nicholas Wolterstorff writes in Lament for a Son:
"How is faith to endure, O God, when you allow all this scraping and tearing on us? You have allowed rivers of blood to flow, mountains of suffering to pile up, sobs to become humanity's song... But I shall not repudiate the past. For this, too, I need you. Help me to integrate my regret, my remorse, my sorrow, my anguish, into my living as a follower of Jesus Christ." — Nicholas Wolterstorff, Lament for a Son
Nothing wasted means: Even the hard conversations, the misunderstandings, the conflicts—God can use all of it. Not to excuse it. Not to minimize the pain. But to redeem it. To bring something good from something broken. This doesn't happen automatically. It requires intention. It requires choosing grace over grudges. Choosing compassion over contempt. Choosing to believe that even this relational complexity is raw material for transformation. 4. Abraham and Isaac on Mount Moriah: The Test That Reveals The story in Genesis 22 is one of the most challenging in all of Scripture. God asks Abraham to offer his son Isaac—the son of promise, the one through whom all nations would be blessed—as a sacrifice. Abraham obeys. He takes Isaac up Mount Moriah. He builds the altar. He binds his son. He raises the knife. And God provides a ram in the thicket. Isaac is spared. The promise is preserved.
"So Abraham called the name of that place, 'The Lord will provide'; as it is said to this day, 'On the mount of the Lord it shall be provided.'" — Genesis 22:14 (ESV)
What could have been the most tragic waste—the death of the promised son—becomes instead a revelation of God's character. The Lord provides. Always. Even when it seems impossible. Walter Brueggemann writes in Genesis:
"Abraham names the place 'The Lord will provide.' The name is not a promise that God will supply all our needs. It is rather a confession that in the moment of greatest testing, God shows up. God intervenes. God provides a way." — Walter Brueggemann, Genesis
Nothing is wasted because God specializes in last-minute provision. In eleventh-hour intervention. In turning what looks like absolute waste into absolute redemption. The test itself wasn't wasted. The fear wasn't wasted. The faith required to obey wasn't wasted. All of it became part of the story that would be told for generations: on the mountain of the Lord, it will be provided. 5. Romans 8:28 Rightly Understood Perhaps no verse is more quoted—and more misunderstood—than Romans 8:28:
"And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose." — Romans 8:28
This doesn't mean everything that happens is good. It doesn't mean God causes evil so good can result. It doesn't mean we should minimize pain or suffering by slapping a spiritual Band-Aid on it and saying "God works all things for good." What it does mean is this: God is relentlessly committed to redeeming every moment of your story. Even the worst ones. Even the ones that feel utterly wasted. God is at work, weaving them into something good. Keller explains:
"God does not promise that he will take away the pain and suffering of this life. He promises something better—that he will be with us in it, and he will use it for his purposes and our ultimate good." — Timothy Keller, Walking with God Through Pain and Suffering
Romans 8:28 is not a platitude. It's a promise. A promise that your pain has purpose. Your suffering isn't random. Your struggles aren't wasted. God is working—actively, intentionally, lovingly—to bring good from it all. Not always good you can see in the moment. Sometimes not good you'll see in this lifetime. But good nonetheless. Eternal good. The kind of good that redeems every wasted season and makes it count for eternity. 6. Suffering to Compassion: The Transformation One of the most profound ways God ensures nothing is wasted is by transforming our suffering into compassion. What once wounded us becomes the very thing that equips us to heal others.
"Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of compassion and the God of all comfort, who comforts us in all our troubles, so that we can comfort those in any trouble with the comfort we ourselves receive from God." — 2 Corinthians 1:3-4
Your pain isn't wasted when it becomes the bridge to someone else's healing. Your struggle isn't wasted when it becomes the testimony that gives someone else hope. Your scars aren't wasted when they become the proof that wounds can heal. Henri Nouwen writes in The Wounded Healer:
"Nobody escapes being wounded. We all are wounded people, whether physically, emotionally, mentally, or spiritually. The main question is not 'How can we hide our wounds?' so we don't have to be embarrassed, but 'How can we put our woundedness in the service of others?'" — Henri Nouwen, The Wounded Healer
This is the economy of grace: nothing is wasted because every experience—even the painful ones—can become a gift to others. The years you thought were lost become the very years that qualify you to speak into someone else's lostness. The seasons you thought were wasted become the seasons that prepare you for kingdom work.

Biblical Parallels

Abraham and Isaac: The Ram in the Thicket (Genesis 22:1-14) The story begins with a test that seems to contradict everything God has promised. Isaac is the son of promise, the heir through whom Abraham's descendants will be as numerous as the stars. To sacrifice him would waste the promise itself. But Abraham trusts. Even when it makes no sense. Even when the cost seems unbearable. He believes that somehow, God will provide. And God does. At the last possible moment, a ram appears, caught in the thicket. Isaac is spared. The promise continues. And Abraham names the place "The Lord will provide." Nothing was wasted—not the fear, not the faith, not the journey up the mountain. It all became part of the testimony: on the mountain of the Lord, provision will be made. Joseph: From Pit to Palace (Genesis 37-50) Joseph's story is one of the clearest pictures of "nothing is wasted" in all of Scripture. Betrayed by his brothers. Sold into slavery. Falsely accused. Imprisoned. For years, it looked like total waste. But God was weaving a story of redemption. The pit led to Potiphar's house. Prison led to the palace. And ultimately, Joseph's suffering positioned him to save not just Egypt, but his own family—the very ones who betrayed him. His words to his brothers capture the heart of "nothing is wasted":
"You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives." — Genesis 50:20
What others meant for evil, God meant for good. What looked like wasted years became the preparation for his purpose. Nothing—not the betrayal, not the slavery, not the false accusations, not the imprisonment—was wasted in God's economy. The Cross: Ultimate Redemption of Waste (Luke 23:33-43) If you want to see God's power to redeem waste, look at the cross. The most brutal, degrading, seemingly wasteful death imaginable. A young rabbi, full of potential, executed as a common criminal. Three years of ministry, ended. Disciples scattered. Hope crushed. Wasted. That's what it looked like. But that's not what it was. The cross wasn't waste—it was the hinge of history. The moment when all waste, all sin, all brokenness was gathered up and transformed. Death swallowed up in victory. The grave robbed of its power.
"Having disarmed the powers and authorities, he made a public spectacle of them, triumphing over them by the cross." — Colossians 2:15
If God can redeem the cross—if he can take the most wasteful, brutal death and make it the source of eternal life—then nothing in your life is beyond his redemptive reach. No season is too wasted. No pain is too great. No loss is too final. In God's economy, nothing is wasted. Not even death itself.

Theological Anchor

"So Abraham called the name of that place, 'The Lord will provide'; as it is said to this day, 'On the mount of the Lord it shall be provided.'" — Genesis 22:14 (ESV)
"And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, who have been called according to his purpose." — Romans 8:28
These two passages—separated by centuries—speak the same truth: God is in the business of redemption. Of provision. Of ensuring that nothing is wasted in his hands. Genesis 22 shows us God's character: he is the God who provides. Even when the test is unbearable. Even when obedience seems to contradict the promise. Even at the last possible moment. God provides. Romans 8 shows us God's commitment: he works all things—not some things, but all things—for the good of those who love him. This isn't wishful thinking. It's covenant faithfulness. God has bound himself to redeem your story, no matter how broken the chapters. Together, these passages form the theological foundation for believing nothing is wasted: God's provision is certain. On the mountain of the Lord—in your darkest moments, your most desperate situations—provision will be made. It may not come when you expect. It may not look like you imagined. But it will come. God's redemption is comprehensive. All things. Not just the good things. Not just the spiritual things. All things. Every moment, every experience, every pain, every struggle—God is working it for good. This doesn't mean the pain wasn't real. It doesn't mean the waste didn't hurt. It means God specializes in turning waste into wonder. Ashes into beauty. Mourning into dancing. Brennan Manning writes in The Ragamuffin Gospel:
"In the economy of God, nothing is wasted. Each tear, each failure, each loss becomes an opportunity for grace. The God who raised Jesus from the dead is the God who redeems every moment of our lives." — Brennan Manning, The Ragamuffin Gospel
This is the anchor: your story is not defined by what was wasted, but by what was redeemed. And in God's hands, everything can be redeemed.

The Wayfarer Moment

The shift from regret to redemption doesn't happen all at once. It happens one memory at a time. For years, I carried a deep sense of regret. Time wasted. Opportunities missed. Relationships broken. Years spent in patterns that brought nothing but pain. I would look back and see waste. Just waste. And the weight of it was crushing. But slowly—so slowly—I began to see differently. Not because the facts changed. But because my understanding of God's character deepened. I started to ask different questions. Not "Why did I waste so much time?" but "Where was grace at work even when I couldn't see it?" And the answers surprised me. The years in the swamp taught me what I couldn't learn anywhere else: my desperate need for grace. The mistakes taught me compassion for others who struggle. The broken relationships taught me the cost of pride and the beauty of humility. Even the wasted years became the very years that prepared me for the work I'm doing now. Nothing was wasted. Not because I deserved redemption. But because God specializes in it. I began doing timeline work—intentionally looking back at my life and tracing the thread of grace through every season. The joyful seasons and the painful ones. The seasons of growth and the seasons of wandering. And in every season, I found the same thing: God was there. Working. Weaving. Redeeming. This didn't erase the pain. It didn't undo the consequences. But it reframed the story. What looked like waste became raw material for transformation. What felt like lost years became the very years that made me who I am. I'm learning to live from this truth: in the economy of God, nothing is wasted. Not the struggles. Not the failures. Not even the years I spent running from him. All of it—every moment, every tear, every broken piece—God is redeeming. Repurposing. Transforming into something eternally valuable. And if God can redeem my wasteland, he can redeem yours too.

Original Writing from the Blog

There's a saying in Christian circles that carries profound comfort: "In the economy of God, nothing is wasted." It means that God does not let a single tear, a single trial, a single act of surrender go unused. He redeems every loss, repurposes every waiting season, and reshapes every broken piece into something eternally valuable. This truth pulses through the story of Genesis 22, where Abraham, in faith, prepares to offer his son Isaac. It's a moment that tests everything—his trust, his obedience, his understanding of God. Yet Abraham moves forward, believing that somehow, the Lord will provide. And God does. A ram in the thicket. A life spared. A promise reaffirmed. In our lives, the "mountain" might look like uncertainty, grief, or letting go of dreams we've clung to for too long. But like Abraham, we are invited to trust—not in outcomes, but in God Himself. The economy of God doesn't work like ours. We try to measure value by outcomes, by progress, by resolution. But God sees value in the hidden things: the unseen acts of obedience, the whispered prayers, the quiet endurance of faith. Even our regrets and failures, when surrendered, become instruments of grace in His hands. So we lay it down again. We trust again. We believe again. Because we know this: in the economy of God, nothing is wasted. Not the waiting. Not the weeping. Not even the wondering. From the WordPress post "Nothing is Wasted" (August 2025)

Song Integration

What the Devotional Captures: The devotional writing emerged from this season of looking back—not with regret anymore, but with wonder. It names the truth: "God does not let a single tear, a single trial, a single act of surrender go unused. He redeems every loss, repurposes every waiting season, and reshapes every broken piece into something eternally valuable." This is the Abraham truth. This is the Genesis 22:14 declaration: "The LORD will provide." Even when it looks like waste. Even when it feels like loss. Even when you can't see how God could possibly redeem this—He will. He does. He is. What the Song Adds: The song takes the devotional's theology and makes it personal testimony. Where the devotional proclaims "nothing is wasted," the song confesses "I tried to hold it all together, afraid of what I'd lose." Where the devotional declares "God redeems," the song wrestles: "I've walked through days that felt like silence, and nights I couldn't catch my breath." Where the devotional affirms "the Lord will provide," the song testifies: "Even when I walk through fire, You stay in the flame." The song moves through three stages:
  1. The Struggle to Let Go (Verse 1): "You asked me to let go of what I held too tight... afraid of what I'd lose." This is Abraham climbing the mountain. This is me gripping my timeline, my plans, my Isaac.
  2. The Valley of Waiting (Verse 2): "I've walked through days that felt like silence... I couldn't see beyond the moment." This is the wasteland feeling. The regret. The "why did I waste so much time?"
  3. The Redemption Discovery (Verse 3): "In the breaking, I found healing. In the loss, I found Your grace. You're the God who turns my ashes into beauty I can't replace." This is the Abraham moment—seeing the ram in the thicket, realizing God provided, understanding that nothing was wasted.
And the chorus—the declaration that anchors everything: "In the economy of Your love, nothing is wasted." Not because my choices were all good. Not because I didn't truly waste years in the swamp. But because God's economy doesn't work like mine. Where I see waste, He sees raw material. Where I see loss, He sees preparation. Where I see ashes, He sees beauty. Why the Song is a Response, Not an Echo: The devotional tells you the truth about God's economy. The song wrestles with whether you can believe it when it's your wasted years, your broken pieces, your ashes. The devotional says, "Nothing is wasted." The song confesses, "I walked through fire" and testifies, "You stayed in the flame." The devotional proclaims theology. The song embodies experience. And together, they answer the question every broken person asks: Can God really redeem this? Yes. He can. He is. He will. Because in the economy of God's love, nothing—absolutely nothing—is wasted.

Song: "Nothing is Wasted"

[Verse 1] You asked me to let go of what I held too tight The plans I made, the dreams I shaped, the pieces of my life I tried to hold it all together, afraid of what I'd lose But love means laying down the outcome And trusting everything to You [Chorus] You will provide, You always do Even when I don't know what You're leading me through Even when I walk through fire, You stay in the flame You hold my sorrow, You know my name In the valley, in the waiting, I have tasted In the economy of Your love, nothing is wasted [Verse 2] I've walked through days that felt like silence And nights I couldn't catch my breath I said I'd follow where You led me But I was scared of what came next I couldn't see beyond the moment Still You whispered, "I am near" You never promised all the answers You only asked me not to fear [Chorus] You will provide, You always do Even when I don't know what You're leading me through Even when I walk through fire, You stay in the flame You hold my sorrow, You know my name In the valley, in the waiting, I have tasted In the economy of Your love, nothing is wasted [Verse 3] So here I am with hands wide open Letting go of what I thought was mine You never asked me for perfection Just a heart that says, "I'll try" And in the breaking, I found healing In the loss, I found Your grace You're the God who turns my ashes Into beauty I can't replace [Bridge] You don't waste the waiting, You don't waste the pain Even when I'm walking through fire or rain Every breath I breathe, every pain I've tasted In the economy of Your love, nothing is wasted [Final Chorus] You will provide, You always do Even when I'm breaking in two Even when I walk through fire, You stay in the flame You never leave me alone in the pain In the valley, in the waiting, I have tasted In the economy of Your love, nothing is wasted [Outro] So I lay it down again Even when I don't understand You are good… and nothing is wasted You are near when I let go You are strong when I feel low You are kind… and nothing is wasted You've seen every tear I've cried Held my heart when hope had died You stayed… and nothing is wasted So I'll trust You in the silence I'll believe You through the dark You are faithful in the waiting You are healing every part I won't fear what comes tomorrow I won't chase what's not mine to hold You are God… and nothing is wasted

Reflections for the Road

These aren't homework assignments. They're invitations to begin living from the truth that nothing is wasted. Questions for the Journey:
  1. What season of your life feels most "wasted"? Be specific. Name it. Write it down. Where do you carry the most regret? Now ask: Where might grace have been at work even when you couldn't see it? What might God want to redeem from that season?
  2. Do timeline work: Map your life in seasons. Draw a simple timeline of your life. Mark the major seasons—the joyful ones and the painful ones. Where do you see patterns? Where do you see the thread of grace? This isn't about dwelling in the past. It's about understanding how the past has shaped the present, and how God has been faithful through it all.
  3. What suffering in your life might God want to transform into compassion for others? Where have you been wounded? What pain have you endured? How might that very pain become the bridge to someone else's healing? Sometimes our greatest ministry emerges from our deepest pain. When we allow God to redeem our suffering, it stops being waste and becomes a gift.
  4. Read Genesis 22 and Romans 8:28 slowly. What is God saying to you about provision and redemption? What are you facing right now that feels like waste? What seems pointless or irredeemable? How might God be inviting you to trust—like Abraham—that on the mountain of the Lord, provision will be made? That all things—even this thing—God is working for good?

Practice: The Timeline Exercise

One of the most powerful practices for embracing "nothing is wasted" is creating a spiritual timeline of your life. Here's how: 1. Draw your timeline On a large piece of paper, draw a horizontal line representing your life from birth to now. Mark major life events—births, deaths, moves, marriages, divorces, jobs, losses, celebrations. 2. Mark the spiritual seasons Using different colors or symbols, mark seasons of spiritual growth, seasons of wandering, seasons of suffering, seasons of joy. Be honest. Don't spiritualize everything. Mark the desert seasons as deserts. 3. Look for the thread of grace Now go back over your timeline and look for moments of grace—even in the hardest seasons. Where did God show up? Where did provision come? Where did you see his faithfulness in hindsight? Use another color to mark these moments of grace. You may be surprised how many there are. 4. Name what you're learning For each major season, write a one-sentence summary of what you learned or how you grew. Even the painful seasons. Even the "wasted" years. You may discover that the seasons you regret most taught you things you couldn't have learned any other way. 5. Write a prayer of redemption End by writing a prayer asking God to redeem every season. To use even the wasted years for his glory and your good. To ensure that nothing—absolutely nothing—is wasted in his economy. This isn't magic. It won't erase the pain or undo the consequences. But it will help you see your life through the lens of redemption. It will help you believe that in God's hands, nothing is wasted.

Closing Image

You're standing on the mountain now. Not Mount Moriah exactly, but your own mountain. The place where you've laid down what you held most dear. Where you've trusted even when it made no sense. Where you've believed for provision even when you couldn't see it. And as you look back down the mountain at the path you've climbed, you see something you missed on the way up. Every step—even the ones that felt like backsliding. Every turn—even the wrong ones. Every season—even the wasted ones. They all led here. Nothing was wasted. Not the swamp. Not the struggle. Not the years of wandering. All of it—every single moment—was woven into the tapestry of your story. A tapestry of redemption. You can see the ram in the thicket now. The provision that came at just the right moment. Not when you expected. Not how you imagined. But exactly when and how it was needed. And you understand: this is who God is. The God who provides. The God who redeems. The God who ensures that in his economy, nothing is ever wasted. You whisper the words that Abraham whispered centuries ago: "On the mountain of the Lord, it will be provided." And you know—deep in your bones, deeper than doubt, deeper than regret—it's true. God has provided. God is providing. God will provide. And because of that, nothing you've experienced, nothing you've suffered, nothing you've lost is wasted. It's all raw material for redemption. All part of the story. All woven into the unforced rhythms of grace. Nothing is wasted. The mountain testifies to it. Your life testifies to it. And the God who brought you here will see to it that every moment—every tear, every trial, every act of surrender—counts for eternity. On the mountain of the Lord, provision is made. And in the economy of God, nothing is wasted.
