item.dc:creator: skyler
item.content:encoded:
Last updated: 2025-10-07 08:59:50
📢 "Dying Changes Everything: A Wayfarer's Journey" is being replaced by Out of the Swamp: How I found TRUTH

MOVEMENT 3: UNFORCED RHYTHMS (The Transformation)

Chapter 10: Deep Roots, Strong Growth

[audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/I-Will-Trust-You-Lord.mp3"] You can spot the difference between a plant with deep roots and one with shallow roots from a single summer. When drought comes, the shallow-rooted plant withers first. Its leaves yellow. Its stem weakens. It looks healthy enough when conditions are ideal, but it has no reserves. No depth. Nothing to draw from when surface water dries up. The deep-rooted plant? It stays green. Not because it's stronger or trying harder. Because its roots have gone deep enough to reach water others can't access. This chapter is about spiritual depth. Not the flashy kind that impresses people. The hidden kind that sustains you when no one's watching. The kind that grows underground, unseen, unremarkable—but makes all the difference when the heat comes. Here's what you're learning: rhythms are good, but rhythms without roots become rote. Practices are helpful, but practices without depth become performance. You need more than sustainable patterns. You need deep foundations. The question isn't just "How do I walk in rhythm?" It's "How do I stay rooted when storms come? How do I keep from sliding back? How do I build a life that thrives, not just survives?" The answer is roots. Deep roots. The kind that reach down to streams of living water and anchor you when everything else shakes. The writing that follows came from my discovery that spiritual disciplines aren't about trying harder. They're about sending roots deeper. About staying connected to the Source in ways that transform you from the inside out.

Key Themes

1. The Work of Putting to Death There's a paradox at the heart of spiritual growth: before roots can go deep into what belongs, they have to let go of what doesn't. Deep roots require putting to death: Pride - The need to be right. The compulsion to prove ourselves. The addiction to being seen, recognized, validated by others. Pride keeps our roots shallow because it keeps us focused on ourselves rather than God. We're constantly comparing, competing, defending, performing. All that energy goes into image management rather than transformation. The antidote isn't self-hatred. It's what Paul calls in Philippians 2 "considering others more significant than yourselves." The humility that says, "I don't have to win this argument. I don't have to prove I'm right. I can be wrong and still be loved." Pride keeps you on the surface, performing. Humility sends roots deep, receiving. Reactivity - Responding from wounds instead of from identity. When someone criticizes you, do you react defensively? When life doesn't go your way, do you lash out? When you feel threatened, do you attack? Reactivity is living from your False Self—the wounded, defended, self-protective version of you. Deep roots grow when you learn to respond from your True Self—the beloved, secure, grounded-in-God version of you. This doesn't mean you don't feel pain. You do. But you don't let the pain control your response. You feel it, name it, bring it to God, and then choose how to respond rather than simply reacting. Isolation - The temptation to withdraw when things get hard. To hide your struggles. To pretend you're fine when you're not. To go it alone because you're afraid of being a burden or being rejected. Isolation is the enemy of deep roots. Trees don't grow in isolation—they grow in groves, forests, communities where their roots intertwine with other roots, creating stability and sharing nutrients. You need community. Not performative community where everyone pretends to have it all together. Real community where you can be honest about your struggles, receive prayer, offer support, and grow together. Deep roots require staying connected even when you want to withdraw. Bitterness - The nursing of perceived injustices. The rehearsal of how you've been wronged. The keeping of records. The refusal to forgive. Bitterness is like poison in the soil. It doesn't hurt the person you're bitter toward—it hurts you. It keeps your roots shallow and twisted, unable to reach the streams of living water because they're too busy clinging to old wounds. Forgiveness doesn't mean what happened was okay. It means you're releasing it so it doesn't control you anymore. You're letting go so your roots can grow deep into grace rather than staying tangled in grievance. This is hard work. Dying work. But it's necessary work. Because you can't grow deep roots in poisoned soil. 2. The Work of Cultivating What Belongs Putting to death is only half the work. The other half is cultivating what belongs—the virtues, practices, and postures that create conditions for deep roots. Humility - Acknowledging your need for grace. Admitting you don't have it all together. Embracing your limits rather than pretending they don't exist. Richard Foster writes:
"Superficiality is the curse of our age. The doctrine of instant satisfaction is a primary spiritual problem. The desperate need today is not for a greater number of intelligent people, or gifted people, but for deep people." — Richard Foster, Celebration of Discipline
Humility is the path to depth. Because humility says, "I need help. I need God. I need community. I need grace." And that acknowledgment positions you to receive what you need. Pride keeps you on the surface, performing. Humility sends roots deep, receiving. Responsiveness - Acting from your True Self, not your wounded self. Learning to pause between stimulus and response. Choosing how you'll act rather than simply reacting. This requires self-awareness—knowing your triggers, understanding your patterns, recognizing when you're operating from wounds versus operating from belovedness. And it requires spiritual practices—silence and solitude to hear God's voice, prayer to seek His guidance, Scripture to renew your mind, community to hold you accountable. Deep roots make you responsive rather than reactive. Grounded rather than tossed about. Stable rather than volatile. Connection - Staying engaged even when vulnerable. Showing up even when it's hard. Choosing relationship over isolation. John Ortberg writes about the importance of spiritual community in Everybody's Normal Till You Get to Know Them:
"Being in community is like being in a pool. It's easier to stay afloat when you're connected to others. Isolation is like trying to tread water alone—eventually, you sink." — John Ortberg, adapted from Everybody's Normal Till You Get to Know Them
Connection doesn't mean perfect harmony all the time. It means staying at the table even when conversations are hard. Staying in the community even when you're disappointed. Staying in relationship even when you're hurting. Because isolation is where roots shrivel. Connection is where they deepen. Forgiveness - Releasing what you can't control. Letting go of the need for justice, vindication, or revenge. Trusting God to make all things right in His time. Forgiveness isn't a one-time decision. It's a daily practice. Sometimes an hourly practice. You choose to release the offense again and again until one day you realize it no longer has power over you. This is the work of cultivating deep roots: putting to death what doesn't belong, cultivating what does. Not by addition, but by transformation. 3. The Tree by Streams of Water The Psalmist paints a picture of flourishing that captures everything deep roots make possible:
"Blessed is the one who does not walk in step with the wicked or stand in the way that sinners take or sit in the company of mockers, but whose delight is in the law of the LORD, and who meditates on his law day and night. That person is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither— whatever they do prospers." — Psalm 1:1-3
Notice the progression: The blessed person doesn't walk, stand, or sit with those who mock God. Instead, they delight in God's Word and meditate on it continually. And the result? They're like a tree planted by streams of water. Planted, not drifting. Intentional, rooted, stable. Not a tumbleweed blown wherever the wind takes it. You've been planted by streams—the water's edge of grace. Now roots are growing deep. Streams of water. The tree doesn't generate its own water. It's positioned by an abundant source. You don't generate your own grace. You're rooted in God's inexhaustible provision. The streams flow constantly. You access them through roots—prayer, Scripture, worship, community, Sabbath. Fruit in season. Not all the time. Not constantly. In season. This is realistic spirituality. There are seasons of growth, seasons of fruit, seasons of dormancy, seasons of pruning. Deep roots don't guarantee constant productivity. They guarantee sustainable fruitfulness over time. Leaf does not wither. Even in drought—hard seasons when surface moisture evaporates, when emotions are dry, when external supports fail—the deeply rooted tree endures. Why? Because deep roots access water others can't reach. This is the stability deep roots offer: not exemption from hard seasons, but endurance through them. Whatever they do prospers. Not prosperity gospel—not "follow these steps, get these results." This is organic flourishing. A well-rooted tree naturally prospers because it's connected to its source. Stay rooted. The fruit will come. Not forced. Not manufactured. Organic. In season. 4. The Promise of Jeremiah The prophet Jeremiah expands this imagery with even stronger promises:
"But blessed is the one who trusts in the LORD, whose confidence is in him. They will be like a tree planted by the water that sends out its roots by the stream. It does not fear when heat comes; its leaves are always green. It has no worries in a year of drought and never fails to bear fruit." — Jeremiah 17:7-8
Notice the difference from Psalm 1: Jeremiah emphasizes trust and resilience. Deep roots come from trusting the LORD—not your performance, not your circumstances, but God. Trust as the foundation. Jeremiah contrasts two types of people: those who trust in humans (cursed, like a bush in parched desert) and those who trust in the LORD (blessed, like a tree by water). Your roots go where your trust is. If you trust yourself, roots stay shallow—limited by your capacity. If you trust God, roots go deep—accessing an infinite source. Sends out roots. Active imagery. You don't passively wait for depth. You actively cultivate it through practices, through choices, through sustained rhythms. But the growth itself is organic, not forced. Does not fear when heat comes. This is the promise: resilience. Heat—trials, suffering, hard seasons—will come. The question isn't if, but when. But deeply rooted trees don't fear the heat. Not because heat doesn't hurt, but because deep roots access water even when surface conditions are scorching. No worries in drought. Not "no awareness"—the tree knows there's drought. But "no anxiety." It sees withering all around but has no worries because its roots reach deep water. This is the unforced rhythm of trust: acknowledging hard realities without anxious striving. Never fails to bear fruit. An even stronger promise than Psalm 1's "fruit in season." Why? Because the tree is constantly connected to the stream. It's not dependent on rainfall (external circumstances). It's rooted by a stream (constant internal source). When you're deeply rooted in God, you don't become fruitless in hard seasons. The fruit might look different—not abundance, but endurance; not productivity, but presence. But you never fail to bear it. 5. Rooted and Built Up in Christ The apostle Paul gives practical instructions for how roots actually deepen:
"So then, just as you received Christ Jesus as Lord, continue to live your lives in him, rooted and built up in him, strengthened in the faith as you were taught, and overflowing with thankfulness." — Colossians 2:6-7
This is the process: receive, continue, be rooted, be built up, be strengthened, overflow. As you received. Paul anchors growth in grace. You didn't earn salvation—you received it. Now live the same way. Don't shift from grace (how you were saved) to works (how you think you'll grow). Deep roots grow in the soil of grace, not striving. Continue to live in him. The word "continue" suggests consistency—the unforced rhythms of the previous chapter. Not a one-time decision. Ongoing, daily, rhythmic living in Christ. Roots deepen through sustained connection, not sporadic effort. Rooted and built up. Paul combines two metaphors: agricultural (rooted) and architectural (built up). Roots grow down—unseen, slow, deep. Buildings go up—visible, structured, intentional. Both are necessary. Deep roots provide stability for strong growth. Strengthened in faith. Faith deepens through practice, teaching, community. You were "taught"—you didn't discover this alone. Deep roots grow in community, with mentors, through Scripture, with accountability. Overflowing with thankfulness. The result of deep roots is overflow. Not scarcity—hoarding grace for yourself. But abundance—so rooted in God's love you overflow with gratitude. Thankfulness becomes the posture of the deeply rooted life. 6. The Disciplines as Roots How do roots actually go deep? Through spiritual practices that position you in the stream of God's grace. Jan Johnson writes about contemplative practices in When the Soul Listens:
"Spiritual disciplines are not tasks to check off a list. They are invitations to be with God. Prayer is not about saying the right words—it's about showing up. Scripture reading is not about covering chapters—it's about listening. Sabbath is not about rules—it's about rest. When we approach disciplines this way, they become life-giving rhythms rather than religious obligations." — Jan Johnson, adapted from When the Soul Listens
The spiritual disciplines—prayer, study, fasting, solitude, service, worship, Sabbath—are how you send roots deep. Not to earn God's favor. But to position yourself where grace can transform you. Prayer - Not just asking for things, but cultivating awareness of God's presence. Learning to abide. To rest. To listen. Scripture - Not just accumulating knowledge, but letting the Word renew your mind, shape your desires, reorder your loves. Sabbath - Not just a day off, but a rhythm of rest that reminds you: you are not what you produce. You are beloved. Solitude - Not isolation, but intentional time alone with God. Away from noise, hurry, and distraction. Space to hear His voice. Community - Not performance, but authentic connection. Confession. Accountability. Mutual encouragement. Shared worship. Service - Not to earn approval, but to overflow from abundance. Giving from what you've received. Loving because you've been loved. These aren't rules to keep or hoops to jump through. They're the practices that create conditions for deep roots. You can't force roots to grow. But you can position yourself by the stream and let growth happen. Adele Ahlberg Calhoun writes in Spiritual Disciplines Handbook:
"We cannot transform ourselves. But we can cooperate with God's transforming work. Spiritual disciplines are the means by which we place ourselves in the path of God's grace. They are how we say yes to the Spirit's work in us." — Adele Ahlberg Calhoun, Spiritual Disciplines Handbook
This is the work of deep roots: sustained, patient cooperation with God's grace. Not earning. Not striving. Positioning yourself. And trusting the growth to come.

Biblical Parallels

The Parable of the Sower (Matthew 13:1-23) Jesus tells a story about a farmer scattering seed. Some falls on the path and birds eat it. Some falls on rocky ground—it sprouts quickly but withers because it has no root. Some falls among thorns that choke it. And some falls on good soil and produces a crop—thirty, sixty, even a hundred times what was sown. Jesus explains: The seed is the Word of God. The soils represent different responses. The rocky ground is particularly relevant to this chapter:
"The seed falling on rocky ground refers to someone who hears the word and at once receives it with joy. But since they have no root, they last only a short time. When trouble or persecution comes because of the word, they quickly fall away." — Matthew 13:20-21
No root. That's the problem. Enthusiasm without depth. Emotion without foundation. The person receives the Word with joy—there's initial excitement, genuine response. But when heat comes, they wither. Why? No root. This is the warning of Chapter 10: don't settle for surface-level faith. Don't mistake initial enthusiasm for deep transformation. Send roots deep now—through sustained practices, patient trust, consistent rhythms—so when heat comes (and it will), you don't wither. The good soil represents those who "hear the word, accept it, and produce a crop" (Mark 4:20). But even good soil requires cultivation. Weeding. Watering. Tending. The disciplines are how you cultivate the soil of your soul so roots can go deep and fruit can come. The Vine and the Branches (John 15:1-8) Jesus uses agricultural imagery to describe the Christian life:
"I am the vine; you are the branches. If you remain in me and I in you, you will bear much fruit; apart from me you can do nothing." — John 15:5
The key word is "remain"—or in other translations, "abide." This is the language of roots. Branches don't try to produce fruit. They remain connected to the vine. And fruit happens naturally. You don't manufacture fruit through effort. You remain connected to Jesus through sustained practices of prayer, Scripture, worship, community. And fruit—love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control (Galatians 5:22-23)—grows organically. But remaining requires intentionality. Branches can be cut off. They can be pruned. They can wither if they don't stay connected to the vine. The unforced rhythms of grace aren't passive. They're active cooperation with God's life flowing into you. You position yourself. You remain. You abide. And the fruit comes. The Fruit of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22-23) Paul contrasts the works of the flesh (what happens when you live from False Self, from striving, from performance) with the fruit of the Spirit (what happens when you live from True Self, from belovedness, from grace):
"But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law." — Galatians 5:22-23
Notice: it's fruit, not works. Works are produced through effort. Fruit grows organically when you're connected to the source. This is the promise of deep roots: not that you'll have to try harder to be loving, joyful, peaceful, patient. But that as you remain connected to Jesus—as your roots go deep into His love—these qualities will grow naturally. Not overnight. Not all at once. But in season. Over time. Through the slow, organic work of roots reaching down to streams of living water. The Tree Planted by Water (Ezekiel 47:12) Ezekiel has a vision of water flowing from the temple, bringing life wherever it goes. And along the banks of this river:
"Fruit trees of all kinds will grow on both banks of the river. Their leaves will not wither, nor will their fruit fail. Every month they will bear fruit, because the water from the sanctuary flows to them. Their fruit will serve for food and their leaves for healing." — Ezekiel 47:12
This is the eschatological vision—the ultimate flourishing. But it's also the pattern for now: trees planted by streams of living water, bearing fruit, leaves for healing. The water from the sanctuary flows to them. You don't generate your own life. You're positioned by the stream of God's grace. And as that grace flows to you—through prayer, Scripture, worship, community, Sabbath—you bear fruit. Your life becomes food for others. Your presence brings healing. This is what deep roots make possible.

Theological Anchor

"I am the vine; you are the branches. If you remain in me and I in you, you will bear much fruit; apart from me you can do nothing. If you do not remain in me, you are like a branch that is thrown away and withers; such branches are picked up, thrown into the fire and burned. If you remain in me and my words remain in you, ask whatever you wish, and it will be done for you. This is to my Father's glory, that you bear much fruit, showing yourselves to be my disciples." — John 15:5-8
This is Jesus's teaching on remaining—on abiding. And it's the theological foundation for everything this chapter teaches about deep roots. "I am the vine; you are the branches." The relationship is organic, not mechanical. Not master and servant. Not employer and employee. Vine and branches. Living connection. Shared life. The sap that flows through the vine flows through the branches. The life that sustains the vine sustains the branches. You're not disconnected from Jesus, trying to imitate Him from a distance. You're connected to Jesus, sharing His life. "If you remain in me and I in you, you will bear much fruit." The condition is remaining. Not striving. Not performing. Not white-knuckling your way to holiness. Remaining. Abiding. Staying connected. And the promise is fruit. Not because you're trying to produce it. But because life is flowing from the vine into the branches. The fruit is inevitable when the connection is sustained. "Apart from me you can do nothing." This is both humbling and liberating. Humbling because it reminds you: you're not the source. You can't generate spiritual life through your own effort. Liberating because it takes the pressure off. You don't have to produce. You just have to remain. Eugene Peterson writes about this invitation in his translation of Matthew 11:28-30:
"Are you tired? Worn out? Burned out on religion? Come to me. Get away with me and you'll recover your life. I'll show you how to take a real rest. Walk with me and work with me—watch how I do it. Learn the unforced rhythms of grace. I won't lay anything heavy or ill-fitting on you. Keep company with me and you'll learn to live freely and lightly." — Matthew 11:28-30, The Message
Unforced rhythms. That's the key. Not forced striving. Not rigid rules. Not exhausting performance. Unforced—natural, sustainable, flowing. Rhythms—repeating patterns, not one-time efforts. Of grace—sourced in God's love, not your striving. "If you remain in me and my words remain in you, ask whatever you wish." Remaining isn't just emotional closeness. It's also letting Jesus's words dwell in you. Meditating on Scripture. Letting it shape your thinking, reorder your desires, renew your mind. As you remain and His words remain, your prayers change. You stop asking for what you want and start asking for what He wants. And those prayers are answered because they're aligned with His will. "This is to my Father's glory, that you bear much fruit." The goal isn't your glory. It's the Father's. When you bear fruit—when love, joy, peace, patience, kindness grow in you—people see it and give glory to God. Not because you're amazing. Because God's grace is transforming you. This is the theological anchor: remain in Jesus. Let His words remain in you. And fruit will come—not forced, but organic. Not manufactured, but received. Not through your effort, but through your abiding. Deep roots make abiding possible. And abiding makes fruit inevitable.

The Wayfarer Moment

Learning to trust the hidden work. For years, I equated spiritual growth with visible progress. I wanted to see results. Measure outcomes. Track my advancement. If I couldn't see it, I questioned whether anything was actually happening. But roots don't work that way. The most important growth happens underground. Unseen. Unmeasured. Unremarkable to anyone watching. Above ground, a tree might look unchanged for months. But below ground, roots are spreading, reaching, deepening. And that hidden work is what makes everything else possible. I learned this the hard way. After coming out of the swamp, after encountering grace at the water's edge, I wanted instant transformation. I wanted to be different immediately—healed, whole, bearing fruit. But God was growing roots. There were days when I felt like nothing was changing. I'd pray and feel nothing. Read Scripture and feel unmoved. Gather with community and still feel alone. But looking back now, I can see what was happening. Roots were going deep. Not dramatically. Not visibly. But steadily. Through sustained practices. Through showing up even when I didn't feel like it. Through choosing connection over isolation. Through releasing bitterness and cultivating forgiveness. The wayfarer moment came when I stopped measuring my progress by what I could see and started trusting the hidden work God was doing. I stopped asking, "Why aren't I different yet?" and started asking, "Am I remaining in Him? Are my roots going deeper?" Because here's what I've learned: surface-level change happens fast but doesn't last. Deep transformation happens slowly but endures. You can manufacture behavior change through willpower. But it won't last. The first time stress hits, the first time temptation comes, you'll revert to old patterns. But deep roots—roots that reach down to streams of living water—create lasting stability. Not perfection. But resilience. Not arrival. But endurance. I still have hard days. Days when I'm reactive instead of responsive. Days when I choose isolation over connection. Days when bitterness resurfaces and I have to forgive again. But I don't panic anymore. Because I know: the roots are there. They're deep. And even when I can't see growth above ground, there's work happening below. This is the invitation: trust the hidden work. Keep showing up. Keep practicing the disciplines. Keep remaining in Jesus. The fruit will come. In season. When roots are ready.

Original Writing from the Blog

Psalm 1: Interpretation for Today's Life Blessed is the one who refuses to press the Easy button by following the ways of the wicked rather than taking the path of integrity and hard work Blessed is the one who avoids temptations of the wicked, like… …Cheating on my taxes by submitting false documentation and using the excuse "The Government owes me this" …Short changing the cashier when I know I was given too much change in return, resulting in a shortage in their cash drawer to be reconciled and flippantly using the excuse "That's their loss, my gain" …Taking credit for someone else's accomplishments to make me look better, rather than speaking the truth and giving credit where credit is due and using the excuse "I did most of the work anyway and I deserve the credit" …Covering up my own mistakes by blaming someone else behind their back and using the excuse "They never do anything worthwhile and this wasn't my fault" …Taking it out on another in fits of anger or other types of control and using the excuse "They never help me out when I need it or give me a break; I'm always bailing them out" …Not trusting you God with my brokenness and failures, and instead turning to addictive behaviors using the excuse "I can solve my own problems; and, God wouldn't help me anyway" …Making myself out to be more important than you God, and thus committing the vilest of sin using the excuse "Who are you God that I would trust you with my problems? You never answer my prayers. I'll fix it myself" Bless us Lord instead when we thirst for your Words of life and meditate on them day and night Bless us when we sing praises and pray to you in our cars on the way to work or school or during our morning devotion Bless us when we pray for others and when we lift them up to you on their behalf Plant us and root us in your Words, like a tree next to a stream of water soaking up the deep waters of life Let our leaves flourish and never wither May our trunk grow strong to withstand life's storms and the never ending attacks of the wicked May you prosper all of our activities… …In our interactions with family and friends and our coworkers …With every conversation we have with those as we go about our day that they may see You living within us …When we are thankful and gracious to those around us and can see when someone needs encouragement in their day …When we offer forgiveness to those who hurt us and when we are quick to say we are sorry when we hurt others …When we do not pass up any opportunity to do a kind deed to the least of these among us May we not be like paper rubbish blown hither and yonder in the wind like the wicked who have no direction or purpose but of themselves May we not stand condemned in the judgement but remain strong in the assembly of the righteous Watch over us, oh Lord, in our walk of righteousness And keep us from the destructive ways of the wicked For you are our God Glory to God in the highest Amen

Song Integration

This writing came from reflecting on Psalm 1 during a season when I was learning what it means to be rooted. To be planted, not drifting. To draw life from God's Word rather than from the world's shallow streams. I was struck by the psalm's contrast: the wicked are like chaff—lightweight, blown about by wind, no substance. But the righteous are like trees—rooted, stable, fruitful. I'd spent too many years as chaff. Blown by others' opinions. Shaped by cultural pressures. Reactive to circumstances. No roots. No stability. No depth. But God was inviting me to something different. To be planted. To send roots deep into His Word, His love, His presence. To become the kind of person who could withstand storms because I was anchored in Him. This interpretation of Psalm 1 was my way of wrestling with what that means practically. Not just theologically. Not just theoretically. But in the daily choices of life. What does it look like to be rooted in God's Word when temptation comes? When shortcuts are available? When everyone else is cutting corners and I could too? What does it look like to be a tree by streams of water when the culture around me is chaff—drifting, rootless, searching for meaning in all the wrong places? The answer, I discovered, isn't trying harder to be good. It's staying rooted. Meditating on God's Word. Praying continually. Practicing presence. Choosing integrity even when no one's watching. Because deep roots produce strong growth. Not overnight. But over time. In season. When the roots are ready.

Song: "I Will Trust You Lord"

Verse 1: I will trust You, Lord, my shelter, my song Planted by Your stream, where my roots grow strong When the heat is near, still my leaves stay bright In the darkest storm, You will be my light Pre-Chorus: Oh, my heart is grounded deep in Your grace Anchored in Your presence, I will stand in faith Chorus: Like a tree beside the river, I will stand so tall Through the fire, through the season, You're my all in all My leaves stay green, my soul stays strong Your love sustains me all life long I will bear Your fruit, Lord, make me new I am deeply rooted in You Verse 2: I will drink Your Word, let it fill my soul Day and night I'll seek You, Lord, You make me whole When the winds arise, I will not be swayed For my roots run deep, I will not be afraid Pre-Chorus: Oh, my heart is grounded deep in Your grace Anchored in Your presence, I will stand in faith Chorus: Like a tree beside the river, I will stand so tall Through the fire, through the season, You're my all in all My leaves stay green, my soul stays strong Your love sustains me all life long I will bear Your fruit, Lord, make me new I am deeply rooted in You Bridge: No fear in the drought (No fear, no fear!) No doubt in the storm (No doubt, no doubt!) Your love is my anchor (My heart is Yours!) I'll trust You, Lord (Forevermore!) Final Chorus: Like a tree beside the river, I will stand so tall Through the fire, through the season, You're my all in all My leaves stay green, my soul stays strong Your love sustains me all life long I will bear Your fruit, Lord, make me new I am deeply rooted in You Outro: Deeply rooted, never shaken By Your love, I stand so strong Deeply rooted, always faithful In Your hands, I belong

Reflections for the Road

These aren't assignments to complete. They're invitations to deepen your roots. Questions for the Journey:
  1. What needs to die so roots can go deep? Look honestly at your life. Where is pride keeping you shallow? Where is reactivity preventing growth? Where is isolation cutting you off from community? Where is bitterness poisoning the soil? Name it. Bring it to God. Ask for grace to let it die.
  2. What practices position you by the stream? What are the rhythms that connect you to God? Prayer? Scripture? Sabbath? Solitude? Worship? Community? Are you practicing them consistently? Or sporadically? Deep roots require sustained connection, not occasional effort.
  3. Where are you trying to manufacture fruit instead of remaining in the vine? Are you striving to be more loving? Trying harder to be joyful? White-knuckling your way to peace? Fruit doesn't come from trying harder. It comes from remaining in Jesus. Are you abiding? Or are you achieving?
  4. What does "fruit in season" mean for you right now? Not every season is fruitful. Some seasons are for growth. Some for pruning. Some for rest. Some for harvest. What season are you in? Can you trust that God is at work even if you don't see visible fruit right now?
  5. Read Psalm 1 and Jeremiah 17:7-8 slowly. What is God saying to you through these images? Don't rush. Meditate. Let the imagery sink in. What does it look like for you to be a tree planted by streams of water?

Practice: Cultivating Deep Roots

Here's a simple framework for sending roots deep through spiritual disciplines: 1. Daily: Drink from the stream Choose one practice that connects you to God daily:
  • Morning prayer and Scripture reading
  • Lectio divina (prayerful Scripture meditation)
  • Journaling prayers
  • Listening prayer in silence
The practice matters less than the consistency. You're training your roots to reach for the stream every day. 2. Weekly: Sabbath rest Set aside one day (or even a few hours) each week for Sabbath. Not as legalism. As gift. Sabbath isn't about what you stop doing. It's about what you start receiving. Stop striving so you can receive rest. Stop producing so you can receive belovedness. Stop proving so you can receive grace. Ruth Haley Barton writes in Sacred Rhythms:
"Sabbath is the most countercultural practice available to us. It is a fundamental way of expressing trust in God's provision. When we cease our labors, we acknowledge that God is the provider, not us." — Ruth Haley Barton, Sacred Rhythms
3. Monthly: Solitude and silence Once a month, create extended space for solitude. A few hours. A half day. A full day if possible. Not just quiet time. Solitude—intentional time alone with God. Away from noise, hurry, screens, people. What do you do in solitude? Nothing. And everything. You listen. You rest. You let God search your heart. You pay attention to what's happening in your soul. 4. Seasonally: Examine your roots Every few months, review: Are my roots going deeper? Or am I staying shallow? Ask:
  • Am I more reactive or more responsive than I was six months ago?
  • Am I more isolated or more connected?
  • Am I more bitter or more forgiving?
  • Am I more prideful or more humble?
This isn't about shame. It's about awareness. Where do roots need to go deeper? What needs to die? What needs to be cultivated? 5. Community: Grow in groves Trees don't grow in isolation. Their roots intertwine with other roots, creating stability and sharing nutrients. You need community. Real community. Not performative. Not surface-level. But authentic connection where you can:
  • Confess struggles
  • Receive prayer
  • Offer encouragement
  • Practice forgiveness
  • Serve together
  • Worship together
Who are your people? Who knows your real struggles? Who prays for you by name? Who holds you accountable with grace? Deep roots grow in community.

Closing Image

You're standing at the base of an ancient tree. Massive. Towering. Its canopy spreads wide, providing shade for acres. How long has this tree been here? A hundred years? Two hundred? More? You walk closer and place your hand on the trunk. Solid. Rough. Weathered by countless storms. Scarred by lightning strikes. Marked by seasons of growth and seasons of pruning. But still standing. You look up into the branches. Birds nest there. Squirrels scamper. Life thrives in the shelter this tree provides. And then you look down. At the base. Where roots disappear into the earth. You can't see them. But you know they're there. Reaching deep. Spreading wide. Anchoring this massive tree so firmly that no storm can topple it. The roots are why the tree stands. Not the visible trunk. Not the impressive canopy. Not the beautiful fruit. The roots. Hidden. Unseen. Unremarkable to anyone walking by. But essential. This is the invitation: send your roots deep. Not for show. Not for applause. Not even for immediate fruit. For stability. For resilience. For sustainable life. The work happens underground. In the quiet. In the daily practices. In the sustained rhythms. In the patient trust. You won't always see results. You won't always feel growth. You won't always sense progress. But if you remain—if you keep showing up, keep practicing the disciplines, keep choosing connection over isolation, keep releasing bitterness and cultivating forgiveness—the roots will go deep. And when heat comes (and it will come), you won't fear. When drought arrives (and it will arrive), you won't worry. When storms rage (and they will rage), you won't be uprooted. Because your roots—hidden, deep, sustained by streams of living water—will hold. And in season, when roots are ready, fruit will come. Not forced. Not manufactured. Not through exhausting effort. Organic. Natural. Inevitable. Because you remained. You abided. You sent roots deep. Like a tree planted by streams of water. Leaves green. Fruit in season. Soul strong. Deeply rooted in the love of God. And that makes all the difference.

item.dc:creator: skyler

📢 "Dying Changes Everything: A Wayfarer's Journey" is being replaced by Out of the Swamp: How I found TRUTH

MOVEMENT 3: UNFORCED RHYTHMS (The Transformation)

Chapter 9: Unforced Rhythms of Grace

[audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/Mindful-Bliss-Male.mp3"] There's a pattern most of us fall into after experiencing dramatic grace: we try to keep the intensity going. We expect every day to feel like the day we left the swamp. Every prayer to carry the weight of that first desperate cry. Every moment with God to match the power of that initial encounter. And when it doesn't—when faith settles into something quieter, less dramatic, more ordinary—we panic. We think we're losing it. Backsliding. Cooling off. So we try harder. Push for the feeling. Manufacture the intensity. Force the experience. But here's what you're discovering: grace isn't meant to be lived in constant crisis mode. Grace offers something better than perpetual intensity. It offers rhythm. Jesus called it "unforced rhythms of grace." Not frenzy. Not performance. Not the exhausting cycle of fall-and-rescue, fall-and-rescue. But rhythm. Pattern. A sustainable way of walking with God that actually fits with how you're made. This chapter is about making the shift from dramatic intervention to daily rhythm. From peak experiences to sustainable presence. From surviving crises to thriving in ordinary faithfulness. The writing that follows came from my discovery that grace isn't just the rescue—it's also the walk. The daily bread. The morning-by-morning manna. The unforced way of living that doesn't burn out because it was never built on hype in the first place.

Key Themes

1. The Set Point Theory: Sustainable Foundations There's a concept in psychology called the "set point" theory of happiness. It suggests that each of us has a baseline level of well-being—a natural temperament that's relatively stable over time. Our daily experiences create fluctuations around that baseline: some days we're up, some days we're down. But we tend to return to our set point. This matters for understanding grace because grace doesn't promise constant emotional highs. Doesn't promise that every day will feel like a mountaintop experience. Grace offers something better: a stable foundation beneath the fluctuations. Not hype, but home. Not peak experiences, but sustainable presence. Not manufactured intensity, but authentic rhythm. You can have a hard day and still be grounded in grace. You can feel sad and still be held by God. You can experience disappointment, frustration, even anger—and still be living in the unforced rhythms of grace. Because grace isn't about eliminating life's natural ups and downs. It's about providing the steady baseline—the set point—from which you experience them. Ruth Haley Barton writes in Sacred Rhythms:
"Spiritual transformation takes place as we are willing to open ourselves to the Spirit of God in our everyday lives. The problem is that everyday life is so daily... What we need are rhythms and routines that create openings in our lives where transformation can take place. We need spiritual practices that enable us to be present to God's transforming work within us." — Ruth Haley Barton, Sacred Rhythms
Unforced rhythms don't mean effortless. They mean sustainable. They mean working with your natural design rather than against it. They mean grace-paced rather than performance-driven. 2. The Manna Experience: Daily Bread, Daily Grace When Israel wandered in the wilderness, God provided manna—bread from heaven—every single morning. But there were rules: gather only what you need for today. Don't try to hoard it for tomorrow. Trust that tomorrow will have its own provision. When Israel first saw it, they said "Man hu?"—"What is it?" The question mark. They didn't recognize God's provision because it didn't look like what they expected. But day after day, as they gathered it and ate it and were sustained by it, the question mark changed to an exclamation mark. "This is God's provision! This is grace made tangible!" The Book of Revelation speaks of "hidden manna" given to the one who overcomes (Revelation 2:17)—bread from heaven, daily sustenance, grace in rhythm. Living in unforced rhythms means participating in a manna experience:
  • You don't have to figure out next month's provision today
  • You just gather today's manna
  • You trust tomorrow will have its own
  • You don't hoard grace; you receive it fresh each morning
This is what Jesus taught His disciples to pray: "Give us this day our daily bread." Not weekly bread. Not monthly bread. Daily bread. Because grace is meant to be received in rhythm—morning by morning, day by day. 3. Survival vs. Thriving: From Crisis to Cultivation There's a fundamental difference between surviving and thriving. Many of us have been in survival mode so long, we've forgotten what thriving looks like. Survival is getting through. Thriving is growing in. Survival is crisis management. Thriving is intentional cultivation. Survival asks "How do I make it through today?" Thriving asks "What kind of life do I want to build?" In the swamp, survival was the only option. You were just trying to breathe, to keep your head above water, to make it through one more day. At the water's edge, you moved from crisis to cleansing. You were still focused on immediate needs—getting clean, finding healing, experiencing rescue. But in the unforced rhythms of grace, you're learning to thrive. You're not just reacting to crises anymore. You're building a sustainable life. You're asking different questions:
  • What do I want to see MORE of in my life?
  • What do I want to see LESS of?
  • What do I want NOT AT ALL anymore?
From these questions come projects, goals, plans. Not frantic New Year's resolutions that set you up for failure. But grace-paced renewal that leads to transformation. Parker Palmer writes in Let Your Life Speak:
"Before you tell your life what you intend to do with it, listen for what it intends to do with you. Before you tell your life what truths and values you have decided to live up to, let your life tell you what truths you embody, what values you represent." — Parker Palmer, Let Your Life Speak
Thriving means learning to listen. To pay attention to the rhythms that bring life. To notice what drains you and what sustains you. Then to build a life—intentionally, gradually, grace-paced—around the rhythms that lead to flourishing. 4. Sabbath Principles: Rhythms, Not Rules Jesus said something revolutionary about Sabbath: "The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath" (Mark 2:27). The religious leaders of His day had turned Sabbath into a burden. An endless list of rules about what you couldn't do. A test you could fail. But Jesus reclaimed Sabbath as a gift. A rhythm. A pattern designed for human flourishing. Sabbath isn't primarily about what you stop doing. It's about what you start receiving. You stop striving so you can start resting. You stop producing so you can start being. You stop proving your worth so you can start remembering your belovedness. This is the heart of unforced rhythms: they're designed for your good. They're not arbitrary rules imposed by an austere God to see if you'll comply. They're life-giving patterns woven into the fabric of creation because God knows how you're made and what you need to thrive. Gerald May writes in The Awakened Heart:
"We are accustomed to thinking of spiritual practice as something we do on our own initiative... But grace is always inviting us into relationship, and the invitation is unforced. There is no coercion in love." — Gerald May, The Awakened Heart
Unforced. That word matters. The rhythms of grace aren't imposed. They're invited. They don't force you into a mold. They free you to become who you actually are. 5. Jesus' Own Rhythms: Withdrawal and Engagement If you want to understand unforced rhythms, watch Jesus. He's the master of sustainable spiritual life. He never burned out. Never collapsed under the weight of ministry. Never lost His connection to the Father. How? Rhythm. Mark 1:35 captures it perfectly:
"Very early in the morning, while it was still dark, Jesus got up, left the house and went off to a solitary place, where he prayed."
This wasn't a one-time event. It was His pattern. His rhythm. Withdrawal and engagement. Solitude and community. Prayer and action. Rest and work. Jesus would pour Himself out in ministry—teaching, healing, casting out demons, engaging with crowds. Then He would withdraw. To a solitary place. To pray. To reconnect with the Father. To be refilled. He didn't wait until He was empty. He maintained the rhythm. Engagement. Withdrawal. Engagement. Withdrawal. Because He lived in this rhythm, He had something to give. Not out of duty. Not out of obligation. Out of overflow. Barbara Brown Taylor writes in An Altar in the World:
"The practice of Sabbath is one of those commanding us to stop. Stop working. Stop wanting. Stop worrying. Just stop and notice that you are more than your accomplishments, more than your to-do list, more than your bank account." — Barbara Brown Taylor, An Altar in the World
Jesus models this for us. Stop. Withdraw. Rest. Reconnect. And from that place of fullness, engage again. This is sustainable. This is the rhythm of grace. 6. The Invitation to Easy and Light Jesus issues one of the most beautiful invitations in all of Scripture in Matthew 11:28-30:
"Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light."
Read that again slowly. Jesus doesn't say, "Try harder." He says, "Come and rest." He doesn't say, "Pull yourself together." He says, "I am gentle and humble in heart." He doesn't say, "My expectations are higher than anyone else's." He says, "My yoke is easy and my burden is light." This is scandalous to those of us who've been trained in performance-based faith. We've been taught that real discipleship is hard. Demanding. Exhausting. That if you're not burning out for Jesus, you're not doing it right. But Jesus says the opposite. Real discipleship—life lived in the unforced rhythms of grace—is easy and light. Not effortless. Not without challenge. But sustainable. Fitting. Right-sized for human beings who need sleep and food and rest and rhythm. Henri Nouwen captures this in The Return of the Prodigal Son:
"I have always been complaining that my work was constantly interrupted, until I slowly discovered that my interruptions were my work... I am beginning now to recognize that the real 'work of my work' is to receive God's blessing each day anew and to let that blessing guide me in my daily life." — Henri Nouwen, The Return of the Prodigal Son
The work isn't producing. The work is receiving. Receiving God's blessing. Receiving daily bread. Receiving grace in rhythm. That's the yoke that's easy. The burden that's light. The rhythm that's unforced.

Biblical Parallels

The Manna in the Wilderness (Exodus 16:4-31) When Israel was wandering in the wilderness, God provided manna every morning. But the provision came with a pattern—a rhythm they had to learn:
"Then the LORD said to Moses, 'I will rain down bread from heaven for you. The people are to go out each day and gather enough for that day. In this way I will test them and see whether they will follow my instructions.'" — Exodus 16:4
Each day. Not each week. Not each month. Each day. This was a test, but not the kind we usually think of. It wasn't a test of their ability to perform. It was a test of their willingness to trust. Could they gather only what they needed for today and trust that tomorrow would have its own provision? Some couldn't. They tried to hoard manna for the next day, and it rotted. They tried to control tomorrow's provision, and it turned to worms. But those who learned the rhythm—gather today's manna, trust tomorrow's will come—were sustained. Day after day. Year after year. Bread from heaven in daily rhythm. This is the pattern of unforced rhythms. Not control. Trust. Not hoarding. Receiving. Not anxiety about tomorrow. Faith that God's mercies are new every morning. Elijah's Rhythm of Rest and Engagement (1 Kings 19:1-18) Elijah had just experienced one of the greatest spiritual victories in Israel's history. He'd called down fire from heaven. He'd defeated the prophets of Baal. He'd proven God's power before the entire nation. And then he crashed. Jezebel threatened his life, and Elijah ran into the wilderness, sat under a tree, and prayed to die: "I have had enough, LORD. Take my life" (1 Kings 19:4). God's response is instructive. He didn't rebuke Elijah for his weakness. He didn't say, "Pull yourself together—you just won a great victory!" He didn't demand that Elijah get back to work. Instead, God gave him what he needed: rest, food, and time. An angel appeared and said, "Get up and eat." Twice. And Elijah slept. And ate. And rested. For forty days. Only after that—after Elijah had been physically and emotionally restored—did God speak to him in the gentle whisper and give him his next assignment. God honored the rhythm. Work. Rest. Engagement. Withdrawal. Victory. Recovery. Elijah had been running on adrenaline and spiritual intensity. God invited him into sustainable rhythm. The Sabbath Rest (Genesis 2:2-3; Mark 2:27) The pattern of Sabbath is woven into creation itself. On the seventh day, God rested. Not because He was tired. But to establish a pattern. A rhythm. Six days of work. One day of rest. This isn't arbitrary. It's design. God made you to need rest. To need rhythm. To need patterns of engagement and withdrawal, work and Sabbath. When the religious leaders tried to turn Sabbath into a legalistic burden, Jesus reclaimed it:
"The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath." — Mark 2:27
Sabbath is a gift. A rhythm designed for your flourishing. It's not about rule-keeping. It's about soul-keeping. The Rhythm of Green Pastures and Still Waters (Psalm 23:1-3) The most beloved psalm in Scripture captures the rhythm of grace:
"The LORD is my shepherd, I lack nothing. He makes me lie down in green pastures, he leads me beside quiet waters, he refreshes my soul." — Psalm 23:1-3
Notice the verbs. He makes me lie down. He leads me. He refreshes. This isn't something you achieve. It's something you receive. The Shepherd knows you need green pastures—places to rest. He knows you need quiet waters—places to be refreshed. And He leads you there. Not through frantic striving. But through gentle guidance into the rhythms that restore your soul.

Theological Anchor

"Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. For my yoke is easy and my burden is light." — Matthew 11:28-30
This is Jesus' manifesto for sustainable spiritual life. Let's unpack it: "Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened" Jesus' invitation is not to the strong, the capable, the ones who have it all together. It's to the exhausted. The burned out. The ones carrying loads they were never meant to carry. If you're tired—not just physically tired, but soul-tired—you're exactly who Jesus is calling. "I will give you rest" Not "I will give you more work." Not "I will give you higher standards." Not "I will give you a more demanding discipleship." Rest. Real rest. Soul rest. The kind of rest that comes not from escaping responsibility but from living in rhythm with grace. "Take my yoke upon you" A yoke is a working tool. Jesus isn't calling you to quit everything and retreat from life. He's calling you to work—but to work in partnership with Him. To let Him set the pace. To let Him carry the weight. To work in His strength, not your own. "Learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart" The teacher matters. Jesus doesn't drive you with shame. Doesn't demand perfection. Doesn't measure your worth by your productivity. He is gentle. Humble. Patient. And as you learn from Him—as you watch His rhythms, adopt His patterns, live in His pace—you discover a different way of being. "You will find rest for your souls" Not just physical rest. Soul rest. The deep, abiding peace that comes from living in alignment with how you were made. From walking in the unforced rhythms of grace. "My yoke is easy and my burden is light" Easy doesn't mean effortless. It means well-fitting. Like a yoke custom-made for the ox wearing it. Jesus' way of life fits you. It's designed for human beings. It's sustainable. Light doesn't mean weightless. It means right-sized. Not crushing. Not overwhelming. Bearable. In fact, more than bearable—life-giving. Dallas Willard writes in The Great Omission:
"Grace is not opposed to effort, it is opposed to earning. Earning is an attitude. Effort is an action... Grace is opposed to earning. Grace is not opposed to effort. Grace is God's freely given presence and help." — Dallas Willard, The Great Omission
Unforced rhythms don't mean no effort. They mean effort aligned with grace. Work done in partnership with God. Striving that flows from rest rather than striving to earn rest. This is the theological foundation: Jesus invites us into a sustainable way of living where we work from rest, not for rest. Where we labor in rhythm with grace, not against it. Where our souls find the deep rest that comes from being yoked to the One who is gentle and humble in heart.

The Wayfarer Moment

The shift from frenzy to rhythm doesn't happen all at once. It happens one choice at a time. For years, I lived in frenzy. Crisis mode. Always reacting. Always behind. Always exhausted. I thought that's what faithfulness looked like—burning out for Jesus. But frenzy isn't faithfulness. It's fear. Fear that if I slow down, I'll fall behind. Fear that if I rest, I'll be lazy. Fear that if I'm not producing, I'm not valuable. The wayfarer moment came when I realized: this isn't sustainable. I can't keep living like this. And God doesn't want me to. I began to ask different questions:
  • What rhythms bring me life?
  • What drains me?
  • What does rest actually look like for me?
  • What does Jesus' invitation to "easy and light" mean practically?
And slowly—so slowly—I started making different choices. I started saying no to some good things so I could say yes to the most important things. I started protecting time for rest, not as an afterthought when all the work was done, but as a priority woven into my rhythm. I started paying attention to my limits and honoring them instead of pretending they didn't exist. I started gathering today's manna and trusting that tomorrow would have its own. This didn't happen overnight. It's still happening. I still slip into frenzy sometimes. I still over-commit. I still try to hoard tomorrow's grace instead of receiving today's. But I'm learning. Learning the unforced rhythms. Learning to walk in step with grace. Learning to work from rest instead of toward it. And here's what I'm discovering: sustainable faithfulness is possible. You don't have to burn out to be faithful. You don't have to collapse to prove your devotion. You can live in rhythm. You can thrive. Not because you've mastered some technique. But because you've accepted the invitation: Come to me. I will give you rest. My yoke is easy. My burden is light.

Original Writing from the Blog

Ebb and flow of the waves running over my toes As I stroll down the shoreline Sun setting slowly over the horizon Red flashes of the sky signaling the end of another day Mind unwinding as I let the stress of the day flee Into mindful bliss Your morning breath flows over my face As I stroll into the pathway through the trees The morning dew accumulates on the ground Streaks of light breaking through the clouds of the sunrise Your words remind me of your ever presence Into mindful bliss Starry starry night, full moon shining bright As I release the burdens of the day I lift my prayers of praise in your name Tears dropping down my cheek Thanking you again for your presence Into mindful bliss This is my story, this is my song, Praising my Savior all the day long; Angels, descending, bring from above Echoes of mercy, whispers of love. Wrapped by rhythms of your grace where I belong Into mindful bliss

Song Integration

The Season of Frenzy: For most of my adult life, I lived at breakneck speed. Always moving. Always producing. Always achieving. My calendar was packed, my to-do list never-ending, my mind constantly racing to the next thing. I wore busyness like a badge of honor. "I'm swamped" became my default response when people asked how I was doing. And underneath the busyness was a driving anxiety: If I stop moving, I'll fall behind. If I slow down, I'll fail. If I rest, I'm weak. I was exhausted. Burned out. Running on fumes. But I couldn't see a way out. The frenzy had become my normal. And then I crashed. Not dramatically. Just... stopped. My body said "no more." My mind couldn't focus. My soul felt hollow. I'd been so busy doing that I'd forgotten how to be. The Invitation to Slow: In that crashed season, a counselor asked me a simple question: "When was the last time you noticed God's presence without trying to do anything with it?" I couldn't answer. Because I didn't know how. Every spiritual practice had become performance. Every quiet time had an agenda. I'd turned even rest into productivity. He gave me one assignment: "Go for a walk. Don't pray. Don't problem-solve. Don't plan. Just notice. Notice what you see, hear, feel. Notice if God shows up." I thought it sounded pointless. But I was desperate enough to try. So I went. Early morning. Walked a trail through trees. And for the first time in years, I just... noticed. The morning dew on grass. The way light broke through clouds. The sound of birds waking. The gentle breeze on my face. And something in me exhaled. This wasn't productivity. It wasn't achievement. It was just presence. And in that presence, I encountered God in a way I hadn't in years. Not demanding. Not driving. Not urgent. Just... there. Faithful. Steady. Like He'd been waiting for me to slow down long enough to notice. What the Writing Captures: The blog writing captures those first moments of learning to notice: "Sun setting slowly over the horizon... Mind unwinding as I let the stress of the day flee... Into mindful bliss." "Your morning breath flows over my face as I stroll into the pathway through the trees... Streaks of light breaking through the clouds... Into mindful bliss." "Starry starry night... As I release the burdens of the day... Tears dropping down my cheek, thanking you again for your presence... Into mindful bliss." These aren't dramatic spiritual experiences. They're ordinary moments made sacred by presence. By choosing to slow down. By paying attention. The phrase "into mindful bliss" became my shorthand for this way of being. Not forced. Not manufactured. Not achieving anything. Just gently, intentionally present to God's presence already there. And that presence—that mindful awareness of grace woven into creation's rhythms—became the foundation for a sustainable spiritual life. What the Song Adds: The song "Mindful Bliss of Grace" takes those contemplative moments and weaves them into a declaration of God's faithfulness. Where the writing simply notices ("ebb and flow," "morning dew," "starry night"), the song proclaims what those moments reveal: "Great is Your faithfulness, steady and true. Mercies each morning are always brand new." Where the writing practices presence, the song testifies to what presence uncovers: God's steadfast love, His holy face, His voice reminding that "love will never fail." The progression in the song mirrors the journey from frenzy to rhythm:
  1. Noticing (Verse 1): "Ebb and flow, the waves embrace my feet." This is learning to slow down, to pay attention to creation's rhythms.
  2. Recognizing (Verse 2): "Morning dew reflects Your tender grace, the sunlight streaks reveal Your holy face." This is seeing God in the ordinary, realizing He's been there all along.
  3. Releasing (Verse 3): "I lift my heart and cast my cares above." This is learning to let go, to trust, to rest.
  4. Testifying (Verse 4): "This is my story, this is my song, praising my Savior all the day long." This is the transformation—from frenzy to worship, from striving to resting.
Why the Song is a Response, Not an Echo: The writing is contemplative—quiet observations of God's presence in nature's rhythms. The song is declarative—a proclamation of what those rhythms reveal about God's character. Where the writing whispers "I notice You," the song proclaims "Great is Your faithfulness." Where the writing practices presence, the song testifies to faithfulness. Where the writing captures moments, the song declares the thread connecting all moments: God's steadfast, never-failing, ever-new mercies. Together, they answer the question: How do you move from frenzy to sustainable rhythm? Not by trying harder. Not by adding more spiritual disciplines. But by slowing down long enough to notice that God has been faithful all along. His mercies are new every morning. His love persists through every season. And when you see that—really see it—frenzy loses its grip. Because you realize: you don't have to earn God's presence through productivity. You don't have to prove your worth through achievement. You don't have to run faster to catch up to grace. Grace is already there. In the ebb and flow. In the morning dew. In the starry night. In the unforced rhythms of creation, reflecting the unforced rhythms of God's love. All you have to do is slow down. Notice. Receive. Into mindful bliss.

Song: "Mindful Bliss of Grace"

[Verse 1] Ebb and flow, the waves embrace my feet, Your whispers call where sea and skylines meet. The setting sun declares the close of day, Your steadfast love shines bright along the way. [Chorus] Great is Your faithfulness, steady and true, Mercies each morning are always brand new. Through every season, Your love still persists, You lead me, Lord, into mindful bliss. [Verse 2] Morning dew reflects Your tender grace, The sunlight streaks reveal Your holy face. Each step I take along the sandy trail, Your voice reminds me, love will never fail. [Chorus] Great is Your faithfulness, steady and true, Mercies each morning are always brand new. Through every season, Your love still persists, You lead me, Lord, into mindful bliss. [Verse 3] Starry skies proclaim Your mighty name, The moon's soft glow reveals Your love remains. I lift my heart and cast my cares above, Your Spirit wraps me in eternal love. [Chorus] Great is Your faithfulness, steady and true, Mercies each morning are always brand new. Through every season, Your love still persists, You lead me, Lord, into mindful bliss. [Bridge] Through trials and storms, through winds that roar, Your steadfast grace remains forevermore. Each tear I cry, each prayer I raise, Lifts me higher to endless praise. [Verse 4] This is my story, this is my song, Praising my Savior all the day long. Mercies descending from heaven above, Filling my heart with Your endless love. [Outro] Into mindful bliss, I rest in Your grace, Each moment I live, I behold Your face. Your mercies endure, Your promises stay, Forever I'll walk in Your holy way.

Reflections for the Road

These aren't homework assignments. They're invitations to begin living in the unforced rhythms of grace. Questions for the Journey:
  1. Where are you living in frenzy instead of rhythm? Look at your calendar. Your commitments. Your daily patterns. Where are you reacting instead of choosing? Where are you driven by fear instead of led by grace? Name it. Be specific. Because you can't change patterns you won't acknowledge.
  2. What does "daily bread" look like for you? What are the daily practices that sustain you? Prayer? Scripture reading? Silence? Journaling? Walking? Are you trying to live off yesterday's manna? Are you hoarding for tomorrow? Or are you gathering today's bread and trusting tomorrow will have its own?
  3. What do you want to see MORE of in your life? What LESS of? What NOT AT ALL? These aren't rhetorical questions. Write down your answers. Be honest. Be specific. From these answers, what one thing could you change this week to move from frenzy toward rhythm?
  4. Read Matthew 11:28-30 slowly. What does Jesus' invitation to "easy and light" mean for you today? Where are you carrying a yoke that's too heavy? Where are you working against grace instead of with it? What would it look like to trade that heavy yoke for Jesus' easy one?

Practice: Creating Your Rule of Life

Many Christians throughout history have created what they called a "Rule of Life"—not rules in the legalistic sense, but rhythms. Patterns. A framework for sustainable spiritual living. Here's a simple process to begin creating yours: 1. Listen to your life What brings you life? What drains you? When do you feel most connected to God? When do you feel most disconnected? Don't rush this. Pay attention for a few days. Notice patterns. 2. Identify life-giving rhythms Based on what you've noticed, what rhythms sustain you? Maybe it's:
  • Morning prayer before the day starts
  • A weekly Sabbath
  • Daily walks
  • Monthly solitude retreats
  • Regular connection with a spiritual friend
Write them down. 3. Build them into your life as rhythm, not rules The difference between rhythm and rules is this: rules say "you have to." Rhythms say "this is life-giving." Don't try to implement everything at once. Pick one or two rhythms and build them into your life this month. Let them become patterns. Then add another. 4. Hold them loosely Life changes. Seasons change. What worked last year might not work this year. That's okay. The goal isn't perfection. It's sustainability. It's learning to walk in step with grace, not trying to earn grace through perfect performance. 5. Review and adjust Every few months, review your rhythms. What's working? What's not? What needs to change? This isn't failure—it's wisdom. You're learning to pay attention to how God has made you and what you need to thrive. Dallas Willard writes: "Grace is not opposed to effort, it is opposed to earning." Your Rule of Life isn't about earning God's approval. It's about creating space where transformation can happen. Where you can receive grace in rhythm. Where you can live in the easy yoke and light burden Jesus offers.

Closing Image

You're not at the water's edge anymore. You've waded in deeper. And you've discovered something surprising: the water has a current. Not a violent current that sweeps you away. A gentle current. A flow. And when you stop fighting it—when you stop trying to control every movement—you realize the current is carrying you. This is what the unforced rhythms feel like. You're not striving anymore. Not forcing. Not manufacturing spiritual experiences or trying to prove your worth through exhausting effort. You're flowing. With grace. In rhythm. Some days the water is calm. You float. You rest. You simply be. Some days the water is active. You swim. You work. You engage. But even the swimming feels different now. You're not swimming against the current, desperately trying to get somewhere. You're swimming with it, letting it carry you along. You look up and see the sun filtering through the water. Streaks of light. Steady. Reliable. New every morning. Great is His faithfulness. You take a breath—deep, full, unforced. And you realize: this is sustainable. This is how you were meant to live. Not in crisis mode. Not in frenzy. But in rhythm. In flow. In the unforced rhythms of grace. You can hear the invitation echoing in the water: Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. And you whisper back, not with words but with the posture of your whole being: Yes. I'm coming. I'm learning. I'm resting in Your easy yoke and light burden. The current carries you forward. Gently. Steadily. In rhythm. And you are, for perhaps the first time in your life, truly at peace. Into mindful bliss.

MOVEMENT 3: UNFORCED RHYTHMS (The Transformation)

📢 "Dying Changes Everything: A Wayfarer's Journey" is being replaced by Out of the Swamp: How I found TRUTH
"Are you tired? Worn out? Burned out on religion? Come to me. Get away with me and you'll recover your life. I'll show you how to take a real rest. Walk with me and work with me—watch how I do it. Learn the unforced rhythms of grace. I won't lay anything heavy or ill-fitting on you. Keep company with me and you'll learn to live freely and lightly." — Matthew 11:28-30 (MSG)
A breath. A shift. The water's edge is behind now. You're clean—or at least, being cleaned. The process continues, but something fundamental has changed. You're no longer drowning in the swamp. You're no longer desperately gasping at the water's edge. You're learning to swim. Better yet—you're learning to float. This is the place of transformation. Not the dramatic moment of crisis or the pivotal encounter at the shoreline, but the steady, daily rhythm of learning to live in grace. The unforced rhythms. For so long, life felt like striving. Performing. Pushing. Proving. Even spirituality became another arena for achievement—pray more, serve more, be more. The Christian life looked like a treadmill set at an impossible pace, and you were exhausted trying to keep up. But Jesus offers something radically different. Not a faster pace or a better technique. Not more rules or higher standards. He offers unforced rhythms. A way of living that flows from grace, not toward it. A life sustained by love, not driven by fear. This movement explores what it means to live in those rhythms. To plant deep roots that draw from living water. To recognize that God is writing a redemption story—and nothing in your story is wasted. To walk in the authority that comes from knowing the enemy is defeated. To embrace each moment as sacred, as an invitation to meet God in the present. The chapters ahead aren't about arriving. They're about abiding. About learning to rest in motion, to work from rest, to live from the overflow of grace rather than the depletion of performance. You've made it through the swamp. You've stepped into the water. Now you're discovering what it means to let grace carry you—to live in the unforced rhythms God designed you for all along.
The Journey in Unforced Rhythms: Chapter 9: Unforced Rhythms of Grace - From striving to surrender, from performance to presence. Discover the sustainable pace of grace—not frantic religious activity, but the steady rhythms of a life rooted in God's love. Learn what it means to work from rest, not toward it. [audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/Mindful-Bliss-Male.mp3"] Chapter 10: Deep Roots, Strong Growth - Like a tree planted by streams of water, transformation happens underground before it's visible above the surface. Explore the hidden work of spiritual formation—putting to death what doesn't belong and cultivating what does. Deep roots produce lasting fruit. [audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/I-Will-Trust-You-Lord.mp3"] Chapter 11: Redemption's Story - Your story is part of God's story—from creation to consummation, from fall to redemption. See how every chapter of your life, even the broken ones, fits into the grand narrative of grace. The gospel isn't just a story you believe; it's the story you're living. [audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/Redemption-Story.mp3"] Chapter 12: Nothing is Wasted - In the economy of God, nothing is wasted—not the waiting, not the weeping, not the wondering. Every tear, every trial, every surrender is redeemed and repurposed. Like Abraham on Mount Moriah, we learn that even our most painful offerings become the ground where God provides. [audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/Nothing-is-Wasted-Remastered.mp3"] Chapter 13: Devil's On The Run - The enemy is defeated—not by your effort, but by Christ's victory. Learn to fight from rest, to resist from a place of authority, to recognize that spiritual warfare isn't about gaining ground but standing firm on ground already won. The devil is a liar, and he's on the run. [audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Devils-On-The-Run-III-Remix-Remastered-Remix.mp3"] Chapter 14: Living in the Moment - Made in the image of God, every moment of your life carries divine weight and purpose. Not yesterday's regrets or tomorrow's anxieties, but this breath, this step, this holy now. God is not just the God of your past or your future—He is the God of today, inviting you to live fully present in His grace. [audio src="https://www.skylerthomas.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/This-Moment-is-Enough.mp3"]

The Invitation

The swamp taught you honesty. The water's edge taught you surrender. Now the unforced rhythms teach you how to live—how to abide, how to rest, how to let grace carry you through every season. This isn't about perfection. It's about presence. It's about learning to walk with God not in the dramatic moments but in the daily ones. Not in the crisis but in the ordinary. Not in the striving but in the surrender. The journey continues. But now you're not alone in the struggle. You're carried by grace, rooted in love, living in the rhythm God designed for you from the beginning. Welcome to the unforced rhythms of grace.
